endomysium  ||  noun connective tissue around and between muscle fibres 
endoneurium  ||  noun fibrous tissue between the individual fibres in a nerve 
endoparasite  ||  noun a parasite which lives inside its host , e.g.  in the intestines .  compare ectoparasite 
endophthalmitis  ||  noun inflammation of the interior of the eyeball 
end organ  ||  noun a nerve ending with encapsulated nerve filaments 
endorphin  ||  noun a peptide produced by the brain which acts as a natural painkiller .   
encephalin endoscope  ||  noun an instrument used to examine the inside of the body , made of a thin tube which is passed into the body down a passage .  the tube has a fibre optic light , and may have small surgical instruments attached .  
endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography  ||  noun a method used to examine the pancreatic duct and bile duct for possible obstructions .  abbr ercp 
endoscopy  ||  noun an examination of the inside of the body using an endoscope 
endoskeleton  ||  noun the inner structure of bones and cartilage in an animal 
endosteum  ||  noun a membrane lining the bone marrow cavity inside a long bone 
endothelial  ||  adjective referring to the endothelium 
endothelioma  ||  noun a malignant tumour originating inside the endothelium 
endothelium  ||  noun a membrane of special cells which lines the heart , the lymph vessels , the blood vessels and various body cavities .  compare epithelium , mesothelium 
endotoxin  ||  noun a toxic substance released after the death of some bacterial cells 
endotracheal  ||  adjective same as intratracheal 
endotracheal tube  ||  noun a tube passed down the trachea , through either the nose or mouth , in anaesthesia or to help a person breathe 
end plate  ||  noun the end of a motor nerve , where it joins muscle fibre 
end stage renal disease  ||  noun the stage of kidney disease at which uraemia occurs and dialysis needs to start .  abbr esrd 
enema  ||  noun a liquid substance put into the rectum to introduce a drug into the body , to wash out the colon before an operation or for diagnosis 
enema bag  ||  noun a bag containing the liquid for an enema , attached to a tube into the rectum 
energy  ||  noun the force or strength to carry out activities  you need to eat certain types of food to give you energy .  
enervation  ||  noun 1 .  general nervous weakness 2 .  a surgical operation to remove a nerve 
engagement  ||  noun ( in obstetrics ) the moment where part of the fetus , usually the head , enters the pelvis at the beginning of labour 
engorged  ||  adjective excessively filled with liquid , usually blood 
engorgement  ||  noun the excessive filling of a vessel , usually with blood 
enkephalin  ||  noun us same as encephalin 
enophthalmos  ||  noun a condition in which the eyes are very deep in their sockets 
enostosis  ||  noun a harmless growth inside a bone , usually in the skull or in a long bone 
enrolled  ||  adjective registered on an official list 
enrolled nurse  ||  noun  second - level nurse 
ensiform  ||  adjective shaped like a sword 
ensiform cartilage  ||  noun same as xiphoid process 
ent abbr ear , nose & throat 
entamoeba coli  ||  noun a harmless intestinal parasite 
entamoeba gingivalis  ||  noun an amoeba that lives in the gums and tonsils , and causes gingivitis 
entamoeba histolytica  ||  noun an intestinal amoeba which causes amoebic dysentery 
ent department  ||  noun a department of otorhinolaryngology 
ent doctor  ||  noun same as otorhinolaryngologist 
enter -  ||  prefix same as entero - ( used before vowels ) 
enteral  ||  adjective 1 .  referring to the intestine .  compare parenteral 2 .  referring to medication or food which is taken by mouth or through a nasogastric tube 
enteral feeding  ||  noun the feeding of a person by a nasogastric tube or by the infusion of liquid food directly into the intestine .  also called enteral nutrition ‘standard nasogastric tubes are usually sufficient for enteral feeding in critically ill patients’ [british journal of nursing] 
enteralgia  ||  noun same as colic 
enterally  ||  adverb referring to a method of feeding a person by nasogastric tube or directly into the intestine ‘all patients requiring nutrition are fed enterally , whether nasogastrically or directly into the small intestine’ [british journal of nursing] 
enteral nutrition  ||  noun same as enteral feeding 
enterectomy  ||  noun the surgical removal of part of the intestine 
enteric  ||  adjective referring to the intestine 
enteric - coated  ||  adjective referring to a capsule with a coating which prevents it from being digested and releasing the drug until it reaches the intestine 
enteric fever  ||  noun us 1 .  any one of three fevers ( typhoid , paratyphoid a and paratyphoid b ) 2 .  any febrile disease of the intestines 
enteritis  ||  noun inflammation of the mucous membrane of the intestine 
entero -  ||  prefix referring to the intestine 
enterobacteria  ||  noun a family of gram - negative bacteria , including salmonella , shigella , escherichia and klebsiella 
enterobiasis  ||  noun a common childrens disease , caused by thread - worms in the large intestine which cause itching round the anus .  also called oxyuriasis 
enterobius  ||  noun a small thin nematode worm , one species of which , enterobius vermicularis , infests the large intestine and causes itching round the anus .  also called threadworm , pinworm 
enterocele  ||  , enterocoele  ||  noun a hernia of the intestine 
enterocentesis  ||  noun surgical puncturing of the intestines where a hollow needle is pushed through the abdominal wall into the intestine to remove gas or fluid 
enterococcus  ||  noun a streptococcal bacterium that lives in the intestine ( note :  the plural is enterococci .  ) 
enterocoele  ||  noun another spelling of enterocele 
enterocolitis  ||  noun inflammation of the colon and small intestine 
enterogastrone  ||  noun a hormone released in the duodenum , which controls secretions of the stomach 
enterogenous  ||  adjective originating in the intestine 
enterolith  ||  noun a stone in the intestine 
enteron  ||  noun the whole intestinal tract 
enteropathy  ||  noun any disorder of the intestine .   gluten - induced enteropathy 
enteropeptidase  ||  noun an enzyme produced by glands in the small intestine 
enteroptosis  ||  noun a condition in which the intestine is lower than usual in the abdominal cavity 
enterorrhaphy  ||  noun a surgical operation to stitch up a perforated intestine 
enteroscope  ||  noun an instrument for inspecting the inside of the intestine 
enterospasm  ||  noun an irregular painful contraction of the intestine 
enterostomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to make an opening between the small intestine and the abdominal wall 
enterotomy  ||  noun a surgical incision in the intestine 
enterotoxin  ||  noun a bacterial exotoxin which particularly affects the intestine 
enterovirus  ||  noun a virus which prefers to live in the intestine .  enteroviruses include poliomyelitis virus , coxsackie viruses and the echoviruses .  
enterozoon  ||  noun a parasite which infests the intestine ( note :  the plural is enterozoa .  ) 
entoderm  ||  noun same as endoderm 
entodermal  ||  adjective same as endodermal 
entonox  ||  noun a gas consisting of 50% oxygen and 50% nitrous oxide that is used as a painkiller during childbirth 
entopic  ||  adjective located or taking place in the usual position .  opposite ectopic 
entropion  ||  noun a turning of the edge of the eyelid towards the inside 
enucleate  ||  verb to remove something completely 
enucleation  ||  noun 1 .  the surgical removal of all of a tumour 2 .  the surgical removal of the whole eyeball 
enuresis  ||  noun the involuntary passing of urine 
enuretic  ||  adjective referring to enuresis , or causing enuresis 
envenomation  ||  noun the use of snake venom as part of a therapeutic treatment 
environment  ||  noun the conditions and influences under which an organism lives 
environmental  ||  adjective referring to the environment 
environmental health officer  ||  noun an official of a local authority who examines the environment and tests for air pollution , bad sanitation , noise pollution and similar threats to public health .  abbr eho 
environmental temperature  ||  noun the temperature of the air outside the body 
enzymatic  ||  adjective referring to enzymes 
enzyme  ||  noun a protein substance produced by living cells which aids a biochemical reaction in the body ( note :  the names of enzymes mostly end with the suffix ase .  ) comment :  many different enzymes exist in the body , working in the digestive system , in the metabolic processes and helping the synthesis of certain compounds .  
enzyme - linked immunosorbent assay  ||  noun full form of elisa 
eonism  ||  noun cross - dressing , when a male wears female dress 
eosin  ||  noun a red crystalline solid used as a biological staining dye 
eosinopenia  ||  noun a reduction in the number of eosinophils in the blood 
eosinophil  ||  noun a type of cell that can be stained with eosin 
eosinophilia  ||  noun an excess of eosinophils in the blood 
eparterial  ||  adjective situated over or on an artery 
ependyma  ||  noun a thin membrane which lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord 
ependymal  ||  adjective referring to the ependyma 
ependymal cell  ||  noun one of the cells which form the ependyma 
ependymoma  ||  noun a tumour in the brain originating in the ependyma 
ephedrine  ||  noun a drug that relieves asthma and blocked noses by causing the air passages to widen 
ephidrosis  ||  noun an unusual amount of sweat 
epi -  ||  prefix on or over 
epiblepharon  ||  noun an unusual fold of skin over the eyelid , which may press the eyelashes against the eyeball 
epicanthus  ||  , epicanthic fold  ||  noun a large fold of skin in the inner corner of the eye , common in babies and also found in adults of some groups such as the chinese 
epicardial  ||  adjective referring to the epicardium 
epicardial pacemaker  ||  noun a pacemaker attached to the surface of the ventricle 
epicardium  ||  noun the inner layer of the pericardium which lines the walls of the heart , outside the myocardium .  see illustration at heart in supplement 
epicondyle  ||  noun a projecting part of the round end of a bone above the condyle 
epicondylitis  ||  noun same as tennis elbow 
epicranium  ||  noun the five layers of the scalp , the skin and hair on the head covering the skull 
epicranius  ||  noun a scalp muscle 
epicritic  ||  adjective referring to the nerves which govern the fine senses of touch and temperature 
epidemic  ||  adjective spreading quickly through a large part of the population  the disease rapidly reached epidemic proportions .   noun an outbreak of an infectious disease which spreads very quickly and affects a large number of people 
epidemic pleurodynia  ||  noun a viral disease affecting the intestinal muscles , with symptoms like influenza , such as fever , headaches and pains in the chest .  also called bornholm disease 
epidemic typhus  ||  noun fever with headaches , mental disorder and a rash , caused by lice which come from other humans 
epidemiological  ||  adjective concerning epidemiology 
epidemiologist  ||  noun a person who specialises in the study of diseases in groups of people 
epidemiology  ||  noun the study of diseases in the community , in particular how they spread and how they can be controlled 
epidermal  ||  adjective referring to the epidermis 
epidermis  ||  noun the outer layer of the skin , including the dead skin on the surface .  also called cuticle 
epidermoid cyst  ||  noun same as sebaceous cyst 
epidermolysis  ||  noun separation of the epidermis from the tissue underneath , usually forming a blister 
epidermolysis bullosa  ||  noun a group of disorders where blisters form on the skin 
epidermophyton  ||  noun a fungus which grows on the skin and causes athletes foot , among other disorders 
epidermophytosis  ||  noun a fungus infection of the skin , e.g. athletes foot 
epididymal  ||  adjective referring to the epididymis 
epididymectomy  ||  noun the removal of the epididymis 
epididymis  ||  noun a long twisting thin tube at the back of the testis , which forms part of the efferent duct of the testis , and in which spermatozoa are stored before ejaculation .  see illustration at urogenital system ( male ) in supplement 
epididymitis  ||  noun inflammation of the epididymis 
epididymo - orchitis  ||  noun inflammation of the epididymis and the testes 
epidural  ||  adjective on the outside of the dura mater .  also called extradural  noun same as epidural anaesthesia 
epidural anaesthesia  ||  noun a local anaesthesia in which an - aesthetic is injected into the space between the vertebral canal and the dura mater 
epidural block  ||  noun analgesia produced by injecting an analgesic solution into the space between the vertebral canal and the dura mater 
epidural space  ||  noun a space in the spinal cord between the vertebral canal and the dura mater 
epigastric  ||  adjective referring to the upper abdomen  the patient complained of pains in the epigastric area .  
epigastrium  ||  noun the part of the upper abdomen between the ribcage and the navel .  also called the pit of the stomach 
epigastrocele  ||  noun a hernia in the upper abdomen 
epiglottis  ||  noun a flap of cartilage at the root of the tongue which moves to block the windpipe when food is swallowed , so that the food does not go down the trachea 
epiglottitis  ||  noun inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis 
epilation  ||  noun the process of removing hair by destroying the hair follicles 
epilepsy  ||  noun a disorder of the nervous system in which there are convulsions and loss of consciousness due to a disordered discharge of cerebral neurones comment :  the commonest form of epilepsy is major epilepsy or ‘grand mal’ , where a person loses consciousness and falls to the ground with convulsions .  a less severe form is minor epilepsy or ‘petit mal’ , where attacks last only a few seconds , and the person appears simply to be hesitating or thinking deeply .  
epileptic  ||  adjective having epilepsy , or relating to epilepsy  noun a person with epilepsy ( note :  the word ‘epileptic’ to describe a person is now avoided .  ) 
epileptic fit  ||  noun an attack of convulsions , and sometimes unconsciousness , due to epilepsy 
epileptiform  ||  adjective being similar to epilepsy 
epileptogenic  ||  adjective causing epilepsy 
epiloia  ||  noun a hereditary disease of the brain associated with learning disabilities , epilepsy and tumours on the kidney and heart .  also called tuberose sclerosis 
epimenorrhagia  ||  noun very heavy bleeding during menstruation occurring at very short intervals 
epimenorrhoea  ||  noun menstruation at shorter intervals than twenty - eight days 
epimysium  ||  noun a connective tissue binding striated muscle fibres 
epinephrine  ||  noun us same as adrenaline 
epineurium  ||  noun a sheath of connective tissue round a nerve 
epiphenomenon  ||  noun an unusual symptom which may not be caused by a disease 
epiphora  ||  noun a condition in which the eye fills with tears either because the lacrimal duct is blocked or because excessive tears are being secreted 
epiphyseal  ||  adjective referring to an epiphysis 
epiphyseal cartilage  ||  noun a type of cartilage in the bones of children and adolescents which expands and hardens as the bones grow to full size 
epiphyseal line  ||  noun a plate of epiphyseal cartilage separating the epiphysis and the diaphysis of a long bone 
epiphysis  ||  noun the area of growth in a bone which is separated from the main part of the bone by cartilage until bone growth stops .  see illustration at bone structure in supplement .  compare diaphysis , metaphysis 
epiphysis cerebri  ||  noun the pineal gland .  see illustration at bone structure in supplement 
epiphysitis  ||  noun inflammation of an epiphysis

epiploon  ||  noun same as omen - tum

episcleritis  ||  noun inflammation of the outer surface of the sclera in the eyeball 
episi -  ||  , episio -  ||  prefix referring to the vulva 
episiorrhaphy  ||  noun a procedure for stitching torn labia majora 
episiotomy  ||  noun a surgical cut of the perineum near the vagina to prevent tearing during childbirth 
episode  ||  noun a separate occurrence of an illness 
episodic  ||  adjective happening in separate but related incidents , e.g.  asthma which occurs in separate attacks 
epispadias  ||  noun a congenital condition where the urethra opens on the top of the penis and not at the end .  compare hypospadias 
epispastic  ||  noun same as vesicant 
epistaxis  ||  noun same as nosebleed 
epithalamus  ||  noun the part of the forebrain containing the pineal body 
epithelial  ||  adjective referring to the epithelium 
epithelialisation  ||  , epithelialization noun the growth of skin over a wound 
epithelial layer  ||  noun the epithelium 
epithelial tissue  ||  noun epithelial cells arranged as a continuous sheet consisting of one or several layers 
epithelioma  ||  noun a tumour arising from epithelial cells 
epithelium  ||  noun the layer or layers of cells covering an organ , including the skin and the lining of all hollow cavities except blood vessels , lymphatics and serous cavities .  compare endothelium , mesothelium comment :  epithelium is classified according to the shape of the cells and the number of layers of cells which form it .  the types of epithelium according to the number of layers are :  simple epithelium ( epithelium formed of a single layer of cells ) and stratified epithelium ( epithelium formed of several layers of cells ) .  the main types of epithelial cells are :  columnar epithelium ( simple epithelium with long narrow cells , forming the lining of the intestines ) ; ciliated epithelium ( simple epithelium where the cells have little hairs , forming the lining of air passages ) ; cuboidal epithelium ( with cube - shaped cells , forming the lining of glands and intestines ) and squamous epithelium or pavement epithelium ( with flat cells like scales , forming the lining of the pericardium , peritoneum and pleura ) .  
epituberculosis  ||  noun swelling of the lymph node in the thorax , due to tuberculosis 
eponym  ||  noun a procedure , disease or part of the body which is named after a person comment :  an eponym can refer to a disease or condition such as dupuytrens contracture , or guillain–barré syndrome , a part of the body such as circle of willis , an organism such as leishmania , a surgical procedure such as trendelenburgs operation or an appliance such as kirschner wire .  
epsom salts  ||  noun same as magnesium sulphate 
epstein–barr virus  ||  noun a virus which probably causes glandular fever .  also called eb virus [isolated and described 1964 .  after michael anthony epstein ( b .  1921 ) , bristol pathologist ; murray llewellyn barr ( 1908–95 ) , canadian anatomist and cytologist , head of the department of anatomy at the university of western ontario , canada . ] 
epulis  ||  noun a small fibrous swelling on a gum 
equi -  ||  prefix equal e
quilibrium  ||  noun a state of balance 
equinovarus  ||   talipes

erectile tissue  ||  noun vascular tissue which can become erect and stiff when engorged with blood , e.g.  the corpus cavernosum in the penis 
erection  ||  noun a state where a body part such as the penis becomes swollen because of engorgement with blood

ergot  ||  noun a disease of rye caused by the fungus clariceps purpurea 
ergotamine  ||  noun a drug that causes narrowing of blood vessels and alleviates migraine , derived from the ergot fungus 
ergotism  ||  noun poisoning caused by eating rye which has been contaminated with the ergot fungus comment :  the symptoms of ergotism are muscle cramps and dry gangrene in the fingers and toes .  
erogenous  ||  adjective producing sexual excitement 
erogenous zone  ||  noun a part of the body which , if stimulated , produces sexual arousal , e.g.  the penis , clitoris or nipples

ery -  ||  prefix same as erythro
erysipelas  ||  noun a contagious skin disease , where the skin on the face becomes hot , red and painful , caused by streptococcus pyogenes 
erysipeloid  ||  noun a bacterial skin infection caused by touching infected fish or meat 
erythema  ||  noun redness on the skin , caused by hyperaemia of the blood vessels near the surface 
erythema ab igne  ||  noun a pattern of red lines on the skin caused by exposure to heat 
erythema induratum  ||  noun a tubercular disease where ulcerating nodules appear on the legs of young women .  also called bazins disease 
erythema multiforme  ||  noun the sudden appearance of inflammatory red patches and sometimes blisters on the skin 
erythema nodosum  ||  noun an inflammatory disease where red swellings appear on the front of the legs

erythr -  ||  prefix same as erythro - ( used before vowels ) 
erythraemia  ||  noun a blood disorder where the number of red blood cells increases sharply , together with an increase in the number of white cells , making the blood thicker and slower to flow .  also called polycythaemia vera 
erythrasma  ||  noun a persistent bacterial skin infection occurring in a fold in the skin or where two skin surfaces touch , such as between the toes .  it is caused by corynebacterium .  
erythro -  ||  prefix red 
erythroblast  ||  noun a cell which forms an erythrocyte or red blood cell 
erythroblastosis  ||  noun the presence of erythroblasts in the blood , usually found in haemolytic anaemia comment :  usually erythroblastosis occurs where the mother is rhesus negative and has developed rhesus positive antibodies , which are passed into the blood of a rhesus positive fetus .  
erythroblastosis fetalis  ||  noun a blood disease affecting newborn babies , caused by a reaction between the rhesus factor of the mother and the fetus 
erythrocyanosis  ||  noun red and purple patches on the skin of the thighs , often accompanied by chilblains and made worse by cold 
erythrocyte  ||  noun a mature red blood cell ‘…anemia may be due to insufficient erythrocyte production , in which case the corrected reticulocyte count will be low , or it may be due to hemorrhage or hemolysis , in which cases there should be reticulocyte response’ [southern medical journal] 
erythrocyte sedimentation rate  ||  noun a test that measures how fast erythrocytes settle in a sample of blood plasma , used to confirm whether various blood conditions are present .  abbr esr 
erythrocytosis  ||  noun an increase in the number of red blood cells in the blood 
erythroderma  ||  noun a condition in which the skin becomes red and flakes off 
erythroedema  ||  noun same as acrodynia erythrogenesis  ||  , erythropoiesis  ||  noun the formation of red blood cells in red bone marrow 
erythromelalgia  ||  noun a painful swelling of blood vessels in the extremities 
erythromycin  ||  noun a antibacterial drug suitable for people who are sensitive to penicillin 
erythropenia  ||  noun a condition in which a person has a low number of erythrocytes in their blood 
erythroplasia  ||  noun the formation of lesions on the mucous membrane 
erythropoiesis  ||  noun same as erythrogenesis 
erythropoietin  ||  noun a hormone which regulates the production of red blood cells comment :  erythropoietin can now be produced by genetic techniques and is being used to increase the production of red blood cells in anaemia .  
erythropsia  ||  noun a condition in which someone sees things as if coloured red 
esbachs albuminometer  ||  noun a glass for measuring albumin in urine , using esbachs method 
eschar  ||  noun a dry scab , e.g.  one forming on a burn 
escharotic  ||  noun a substance which produces an eschar 
escherichia  ||  noun a bacterium commonly found in faeces 
escherichia coli  ||  noun a gram - negative bacterium associated with acute gastroenteritis .  also called e .  coli 
escort nurse  ||  noun a nurse who goes with patients to the operating theatre and back again to the ward 
esmarchs bandage  ||  noun a rubber band wrapped round a limb as a tourniquet before a surgical operation and left in place during the operation so as to keep the site free of blood [described 1869 .  after johann friedrich august von esmarch ( 1823– 1908 ) , professor of surgery at kiel , germany . ] 
esophagus  ||  noun us spelling of oesophagus 
esotropia  ||  noun a type of squint , where the eyes both look towards the nose .  also called convergent strabismus 
espundia  ||   leishmaniasis 
esr abbr erythrocyte sedimentation rate 
esrd abbr end - stage renal disease 
essence  ||  noun a concentrated oil from a plant , used in cosmetics , and sometimes as analgesics or antiseptics 
essential  ||  adjective 1 .  extremely important  it is essential to keep accurate records .  2 .  necessary for health  essential nutrients 3 .  without obvious cause  essential hypertension also called idiopathic 4 .  extracted from a plant  essential oil 
essential amino acid  ||  noun an amino acid which is necessary for growth but which cannot be synthesised in the body and has to be obtained from the food supply comment :  the essential amino acids are :  isoleucine , leucine , lysine , methionine , phenylalanine , threonine , tryptophan and valine .  
essential dysmenorrhoea  ||  noun same as primary dysmenorrhoea 
essential element  ||  noun a chemical element which is necessary to the bodys growth or function , e.g.  carbon , oxygen , hydrogen and nitrogen 
essential fatty acid  ||  noun an unsaturated fatty acid which is necessary for growth and health .  abbr efa comment :  the essential fatty acids are linoleic acid , linolenic acid and arachidonic acid .  
essential hyperkinesia  ||  noun a condition of children where their movements are excessive and repeated 
essential hypertension  ||  noun high blood pressure without any obvious cause 
essential oil  ||  noun a medicinal or fragrant oil distilled from some part of a plant 
essential tremor  ||  noun an involuntary slow trembling movement of the hands often seen in elderly people 
essential uterine haemorrhage  ||  noun heavy uterine bleeding for which there is no obvious cause 
estrogen  ||  noun us same as oestrogen 
ethambutol  ||  noun a drug that is part of the treatment for bacterial infections such as tuberculosis 
ethanol  ||  noun a colourless liquid , present in alcoholic drinks such as whisky , gin and vodka , and also used in medicines and as a disinfectant .  also called ethyl alcohol .   pure alcohol 
ethene  ||  noun same as ethylene 
ether  ||  noun an anaesthetic substance , now rarely used 
ethical  ||  adjective 1 .  concerning ethics 2 .  referring to a drug available on prescription only 
ethical committee  ||  noun a group of specialists who monitor experiments involving human beings or who regulate the way in which members of the medical profession conduct themselves 
ethinyloestradiol  ||  noun an artificial hormone related to oestrogen that is effective in small doses .  it forms part of hormone replacement therapy .  
ethmoid  ||  , ethmoidal  ||  adjective referring to the ethmoid bone or near to the ethmoid bone 
ethmoidal sinuses  ||  plural noun air cells inside the ethmoid bone 
ethmoid bone  ||  noun a bone which forms the top of the nasal cavity and part of the orbits 
ethmoidectomy  ||  noun an operation to remove the lining between the sinuses 
ethmoiditis  ||  noun inflammation of the ethmoid bone or of the ethmoidal sinuses 
ethnic  ||  adjective relating to a culturally or racially distinctive group of people 
ethyl alcohol  ||  noun same as ethanol 
ethylene  ||  noun a gas used as an an - aesthetic 
ethylestrenol  ||  noun an anabolic steroid 
etiology  ||  noun us same as aetiology 
eu -  ||  prefix good , well 
eubacteria  ||  noun true bacteria with rigid cell walls 
eucalyptol  ||  noun a substance obtained from eucalyptus oil 
eucalyptus  ||  noun a genus of tree growing mainly in australia , from which a strongly smelling oil is distilled 
eucalyptus oil  ||  noun an aromatic medicinal oil distilled from the leaves of various species of tree in the genus eucalyptus comment :  eucalyptus oil is used in pharmaceutical products especially to relieve congestion in the respiratory passages .  
eugenics  ||  noun the study of how to improve the human race by genetic selection
