euplastic  ||  adjective referring to tissue which heals well 
eustachian canal  ||  noun a passage through the porous bone forming the outside part of the eustachian tube 
eustachian tube  ||  noun the tube which connects the pharynx to the middle ear .  see illustration at ear in supplement [described 1562 , but actually named after eustachio by valsalva a century later .  bartolomeo eustachio ( 1520–74 ) , physician to the pope and professor of anatomy in rome . ] comment :  the eustachian tubes balance the air pressure on each side of the eardrum .  when a person swallows or yawns , air is allowed into the eustachian tubes and equalises the pressure with the normal atmospheric pressure outside the body .  the tubes can be blocked by an infection , as in a cold , or by pressure differences , as inside an aircraft , and if they are blocked , the hearing is impaired .  
euthanasia  ||  noun the painless killing of an incurably ill person or someone in a permanent coma in order to end their distress .  also called mercy killing ( note :  this practice is illegal in most countries .  ) 
euthanise  ||  , euthanize verb to kill an incurably ill person or someone in a permanent coma 
euthyroid  ||  noun a condition where the thyroid is functioning normally 
euthyroidism  ||  , euthyroid state  ||  noun the fact of having a healthy thyroid gland 
eutocia  ||  noun a standard childbirth 
evacuant  ||  noun a medicine which makes a person have a bowel movement 
evacuate  ||  verb to discharge faeces from the bowel , or to have a bowel movement 
evacuation  ||  noun the act of removing the contents of something , especially discharging faeces from the bowel 
evacuation of retained products of conception  ||  noun a d & c operation performed after an abortion or miscarriage to ensure the uterus is left empty .  abbr erpc 
evacuator  ||  noun an instrument used to empty a cavity such as the bladder or bowel 
evaluate  ||  verb 1 .  to examine and calculate the quantity or level of something  the laboratory is still evaluating the results of the tests .  2 .  to examine someone and calculate the treatment required ‘…all patients were evaluated and followed up at the hypertension unit’ [british medical journal] 
evaluation  ||  noun the act of examining and calculating the quantity or level of something  in further evaluation of these patients no side - effects of the treatment were noted .  ‘…evaluation of fetal age and weight has proved to be of value in the clinical management of pregnancy , particularly in high - risk gestations’ [southern medical journal] 
eventration  ||  noun the pushing of the intestine through the wall of the abdomen 
eversion  ||  noun the act of turning towards the outside or turning inside out .  see illustration at anatomical terms in supplement  eversion of the cervix a condition after laceration during childbirth , where the edges of the cervix sometimes turn outwards 
evertor  ||  noun a muscle which makes a limb turn outwards 
evidence - based  ||  adjective based on the results of well - designed trials of specific types of treatment for specific conditions  evidence - based practice 
evidence - based medicine  ||  noun medical practice where findings from research are used as the basis for decisions 
evisceration  ||  noun 1 .  the surgical removal of the abdominal viscera .  also called exenteration 2 .  removal of the contents of an organ  evisceration of the eye surgical removal of the contents of an eyeball 
evolution  ||  noun a process of change in organisms which takes place over a very long period involving many generations 
evulsion  ||  noun the act of extracting something by force 
ewings tumour  ||  , ewings sarcoma  ||  noun a malignant tumour in the marrow of a long bone [described 1922 .  after james ewing ( 1866–1943 ) , professor of pathology at cornell university , new york , usa . ] 
ex -  ||  prefix same as exo - ( used before vowels ) 
exacerbate  ||  verb to make a condition more severe  the cold damp weather will only exacerbate his chest condition .  
exacerbation  ||  noun 1 .  the fact of making a condition worse 2 .  a period when a condition becomes worse ‘…patients were re - examined regularly or when they felt they might be having an exacerbation .  exacerbation rates were calculated from the number of exacerbations during the study’ [lancet] 
examination  ||  noun 1 .  an act of looking at someone or something carefully  from the examination of the x - ray photographs , it seems that the tumour has not spread .  2 .  the act of looking at someone to find out what is wrong with him or her  the surgeon carried out a medical examination before operating .  3 .  a written or oral test to see if a student is progressing satisfactorily ( note :  in this sense , often abbreviated to exam .  ) 
examine  ||  verb 1 .  to look at or to investigate someone or something carefully  the tissue samples were examined in the laboratory .  2 .  to look at and test someone to find out what is wrong with him or her  the doctor examined the patients heart .  
exanthem  ||  noun a skin rash found with infectious diseases like measles or chickenpox 
exanthematous  ||  adjective referring to an exanthem or like an exanthem 
exanthem subitum  ||  noun same as roseola infantum 
excavator  ||  noun a surgical instrument shaped like a spoon 
excavatum  ||   pectus excavatum 
exception  ||  noun 1 .  something that does not fit into or is excluded from a general rule or pattern 2 .  the act or condition of being excluded 
excess  ||  noun too much of a substance  the gland was producing an excess of hormones .   the body could not cope with an excess of blood sugar .   in excess of more than  short men who weigh in excess of 100 kilos are very overweight .  
excessive  ||  adjective more than normal  the patient was passing excessive quantities of urine .   the doctor noted an excessive amount of bile in the patients blood .  
excessively  ||  adverb too much  she has an excessively high blood pressure .   if the patient sweats excessively , it may be necessary to cool his body with cold compresses .  
exchange transfusion  ||  noun a method of treating leukaemia or erythroblastosis in newborn babies , where almost all the blood is removed from the body and replaced with healthy blood 
excipient  ||  noun a substance added to a drug so that it can be made into a pill 
excise  ||  verb to cut something out 
excision  ||  noun an operation by a surgeon to cut and remove part of the body such as a growth .  compare incision 
excitation  ||  noun the state of being mentally or physically aroused 
excitatory  ||  adjective tending to excite 
excite  ||  verb 1 .  to stimulate someone or something 2 .  to give an impulse to a nerve or muscle 
excited  ||  adjective 1 .  very lively and happy 2 .  aroused 
excitement  ||  noun 1 .  the act of being excited 2 .  the second stage of anaesthesia 
excoriation  ||  noun a raw skin surface or mucous membrane after rubbing or burning 
excrement  ||  noun same as faeces 
excrescence  ||  noun a growth on the skin 
excreta  ||  plural noun waste material from the body , especially faeces 
excrete  ||  verb to pass waste matter out of the body , especially to discharge faeces  the urinary system separates waste liquids from the blood and excretes them as urine .  
excretion  ||  noun the act of passing waste matter , e.g.  faeces , urine or sweat , out of the body 
excruciating  ||  adjective extremely painful  he had excruciating pains in his head .  
exenteration  ||  noun same as evisceration 
exercise  ||  noun 1 .  physical or mental activity , especially the active use of the muscles as a way of keeping fit , correcting a deformity or strengthening a part  regular exercise is good for your heart .   he doesn’t do or take enough exercise .  2 .  a particular movement or action designed to use and strengthen the muscles  verb to take exercise , or exert part of the body in exercise  he exercises twice a day to keep fit .  
exercise cycle  ||  noun a type of cycle which is fixed to the floor , so that someone can pedal on it for exercise 
exercise - induced asthma  ||  noun asthma which is caused by exercise such as running or cycling .  abbr eia 
exertion  ||  noun physical activity 
exfoliation  ||  noun the loss of layers of tissue such as sunburnt skin 
exfoliative  ||  adjective referring to exfoliation 
exfoliative dermatitis  ||  noun a typical form of dermatitis where the skin becomes red and comes off in flakes 
exhalation  ||  noun 1 .  the act of breathing out 2 .  air which is breathed out  opposite inhalation 
exhale  ||  verb to breathe out .  opposite inhale 
exhaust  ||  verb to tire someone out 
exhaustion  ||  noun extreme tiredness or fatigue 
exhibitionism  ||  noun a desire to show the genitals to a person of the opposite sex 
exo -  ||  prefix out of , outside 
exocrine  ||  adjective  exocrine secretions of the pancreas enzymes carried from the pancreas to the second part of the duodenum 
exocrine gland  ||  noun a gland with ducts which channel secretions to particular parts of the body such as the liver , the sweat glands , the pancreas and the salivary glands .  compare endocrine gland 
exogenous  ||  adjective developing or caused by something outside the organism .  compare endogenous 
exomphalos  ||  noun same as umbilical hernia 
exophthalmic goitre  ||  noun a form of hyperthyroidism , in which the neck swells and the eyes protrude .  also called graves’ disease 
exophthalmos  ||  noun protruding eyeballs 
exoskeleton  ||  noun the outer skeleton of some animals such as insects .  compare endoskeleton 
exostosis  ||  noun a benign growth on the surface of a bone 
exotic  ||  adjective referring to a disease which occurs in a foreign country 
exotoxin  ||  noun a poison , produced by bacteria , which affects parts of the body away from the place of infection , e.g.  the toxins which cause botulism or tetanus comment :  diphtheria is caused by a bacillus .  the exotoxin released causes the generalised symptoms of the disease such as fever and rapid pulse while the bacillus itself is responsible for the local symptoms in the upper throat .  
exotropia  ||  noun same as divergent strabismus 
expectant mother  ||  noun a pregnant woman 
expected date of delivery  ||  noun the day on which a doctor calculates that the birth of a baby will take place 
expectorant  ||  noun a drug which helps someone to cough up phlegm 
expectorate  ||  verb to cough up phlegm or sputum from the respiratory passages 
expectoration  ||  noun the act of coughing up fluid or phlegm from the respiratory tract 
expel  ||  verb to send something out of the body  air is expelled from the lungs when a person breathes out .  
experiential learning  ||  noun the process of learning from experience 
experiment  ||  noun a scientific test conducted under set conditions  the scientists did some experiments to try the new drug on a small sample of people .  
expert patient  ||  noun a patient with a long - term illness who has been taught how to manage his or her own medical care 
expiration  ||  noun 1 .  the act of breathing out , or pushing air out of the lungs  expiration takes place when the chest muscles relax and the lungs become smaller .  opposite inspiration 2 .  death 3 .  dying 
expiratory  ||  adjective referring to the process of breathing out 
expire  ||  verb 1 .  to breathe out 2 .  to die 
explant  ||  noun tissue taken from a body and grown in a culture in a laboratory  verb 1 .  to take tissue from a body and grow it in a culture in a laboratory 2 .  to remove an implant 
explantation  ||  noun 1 .  the act of taking tissue from a body and growing it in a culture in a laboratory 2 .  the removal of an implant 
exploration  ||  noun a procedure or surgical operation where the aim is to discover the cause of symptoms or the nature and extent of an illness 
exploratory  ||  adjective referring to an exploration 
exploratory surgery  ||  noun a surgical operation in which the aim is to discover the cause of a persons symptoms or the nature and extent of an illness 
explore  ||  verb to examine a part of the body in order to make a diagnosis 
expose  ||  verb 1 .  to show something which was hidden  the operation exposed a generalised cancer .   the report exposed a lack of medical care on the part of some of the hospital staff .  2 .  to place something or someone under the influence of something  he was exposed to the disease for two days .   she was exposed to a lethal dose of radiation .  
exposure  ||  noun 1 .  the fact of being exposed to something  his exposure to radiation 2 .  the fact of being damp , cold and with no protection from the weather  the survivors of the crash were all suffering from exposure after spending a night in the snow .  
express  ||  verb to squeeze liquid or air out of something , especially to squeeze out breast milk for a baby to feed on later 
expression  ||  noun 1 .  the look on a persons face which shows what he or she thinks and feels  his expression showed that he was annoyed .  2 .  the act of pushing something out of the body  the expression of the fetus and placenta during childbirth 
exquisitely tender  ||  adjective producing a sharp localised pain or tenderness when touched 
exsanguinate  ||  verb to drain blood from the body 
exsanguination  ||  noun the removal of blood from the body 
exsufflation  ||  noun an act of forcing breath out of the body 
extend  ||  verb to stretch out , or cause something to stretch out  the patient is unable to extend his arms fully .  
extension  ||  noun 1 .  the stretching or straightening out of a joint 2 .  the stretching of a joint by traction 
extensor  ||  , extensor muscle  ||  noun a muscle which makes a joint become straight .  compare flexor 
exterior  ||  noun the outside of something 
exteriorisation  ||  , exteriorization noun a surgical operation to bring an internal organ to the outside surface of the body 
externa  ||   otitis externa 
external  ||  adjective on the outside , especially outside the surface of the body .  opposite internal  the lotion is for external use only it should only be used on the outside of the body 
external auditory canal  ||  , external auditory meatus  ||  noun a tube in the skull leading from the outer ear to the eardrum .  see illustration at earin supplement 
external cardiac massage  ||  noun a method of making someones heart start beating again by rhythmic pressing on the breastbone 
external ear  ||  noun same as outer ear 
external haemorrhoids  ||  plural noun haemorrhoids in the skin just outside the anus 
external iliac artery  ||  noun an artery which branches from the aorta in the abdomen and leads to the leg 
external jugular  ||  noun the main jugular vein in the neck , leading from the temporal vein 
externally  ||  adverb on the outside of the body  the ointment should only be used externally .  external nares plural noun same as anterior nares 
external oblique  ||  noun an outer muscle covering the abdomen 
external otitis  ||  noun same as otitis externa 
external respiration  ||  noun the part of respiration concerned with oxygen in the air being exchanged in the lungs for carbon dioxide from the blood 
exteroceptor  ||  noun a sensory nerve which is affected by stimuli from outside the body , e.g.  in the eye or ear 
extinction  ||  noun 1 .  the destruction or stopping of something 2 .  the lessening or stopping of a conditioned behavioural response through lack of reinforcement 
extirpate  ||  verb to remove something by surgery 
extirpation  ||  noun the total removal of a structure , an organ or growth by surgery 
extra -  ||  prefix outside 
extracapsular  ||  adjective outside a capsule 
extracapsular fracture  ||  noun a fracture of the upper part of the femur , which does not involve the capsule round the hip joint 
extracellular  ||  adjective outside cells
extracellular fluid  ||  noun a fluid which surrounds cells 
extract noun  ||  a preparation made by removing water or alcohol from a substance , leaving only the essence  liver extract concentrated essence of liver  verb  ||  to take out something  adrenaline extracted from the animals adrenal glands is used in the treatment of asthma .  ‘…all the staff are rgns , partly because they do venesection , partly because they work in plasmapheresis units which extract plasma and return red blood cells to the donor’ [nursing times] 
extraction  ||  noun 1 .  the removal of part of the body , especially a tooth 2 .  in obstetrics , delivery , usually a breech presentation , which needs medical assistance 
extradural  ||  adjective same as epidural 
extradural haematoma  ||  noun a blood clot which forms in the head outside the dura mater , caused by a blow 
extradural haemorrhage  ||  noun a serious condition where bleeding occurs between the dura mater and the skull 
extraembryonic  ||  adjective referring to part of a fertilised ovum , such as the amnion , allantois and chorion which is not part of the embryo 
extraembryonic membranes  ||  plural noun membranes which are not part of the embryo 
extrapleural  ||  adjective outside the pleural cavity 
extrapyramidal  ||  adjective outside the pyramidal tracts 
extrapyramidal system  ||  noun a motor system which carries motor nerves outside the pyramidal system 
extrapyramidal tracts  ||  plural noun same as extrapyramidal system 
extrasensory  ||  adjective involving perception by means other than the usual five senses 
extrasystole  ||  noun same as ectopic heartbeat 
extrauterine  ||  adjective occurring or developing outside the uterus 
extrauterine pregnancy  ||  noun same as ectopic pregnancy 
extravasation  ||  noun a situation where a bodily fluid , such as blood or secretions , escapes into tissue 
extraversion  ||  noun same as extroversion 
extravert  ||  noun same as extrovert 
extremities  ||  plural noun the parts of the body at the ends of limbs , e.g.  the fingers , toes , nose and ears 
extremity  ||  noun 1 .  a limb 2 .  the part of a limb farthest away from the body , especially the hand or foot 3 .  a situation or state of great distress or danger 4 .  the greatest intensity of something 
extrinsic  ||  adjective external , originating outside a structure 
extrinsic allergic alveolitis  ||  noun a condition in which the lungs are allergic to fungus and other allergens 
extrinsic factor  ||  noun a former term for vitamin b12 , which is necessary for the production of red blood cells 
extrinsic ligament  ||  noun a ligament between the bones in a joint which is separate from the joint capsule 
extrinsic muscle  ||  noun a muscle which is some way away from the part of the body which it operates 
extroversion  ||  noun 1 .  ( in psychology ) a condition in which a person is interested in people and things other than themselves 2 .  a congenital turning of an organ inside out 
extrovert  ||  noun a person who is interested in people and things in the external world 
extroverted  ||  adjective 1 .  ( of a person ) interested in people and things other than oneself 2 .  ( of an organ ) turned inside out 
extubation  ||  noun the removal of a tube after intubation 
exudate  ||  noun fluid which is deposited on the surface of tissue as the result of a condition or disease 
exudation  ||  noun the escape of material such as fluid or cells into tissue as a defence mechanism 
eye  ||  noun the part of the body with which a person sees ( note :  for other terms referring to the eye , see ocular , optic and words beginning with oculo -  , ophth -  , ophthalm -  , ophthalmo -  .  ) 
eyeball  ||  noun the round ball of tissue through which light passes , located in the eye socket and controlled by various muscles comment :  light rays enter the eye through the cornea , pass through the pupil and are refracted through the aqueous humour onto the lens , which then focuses the rays through the vitreous humour onto the retina at the back of the eyeball .  impulses from the retina pass along the optic nerve to the brain .  
eye bank  ||  noun a place where parts of eyes given by donors can be kept for use in grafts 
eyebath  ||  noun a small dish into which a solution can be put for bathing the eye 
eyebrow  ||  noun an arch of skin with a line of hair above the eye 
eye drops  ||  plural noun medicine in liquid form which is put into the eye in small amounts 
eyeglasses  ||  plural noun us glasses or spectacles for correcting vision 
eyelash  ||  noun a small hair which grows out from the edge of the eyelid 
eyelid  ||  noun a piece of skin which covers the eye .  also called blepharon , palpebra ( note :  for other terms referring to the eyelids , see words beginning with blephar -  , blepharo -  .  ) 
eye ointment  ||  noun an ointment in a special tube to be used in eye treatment 
eyesight  ||  noun the ability to see o he has got very good eyesight .  o failing eyesight is common in elderly people .  
eye socket  ||  noun same as orbit 
eye specialist  ||  noun same as ophthalmologist 
eyestrain  ||  noun tiredness in the muscles of the eye with a headache , which may be caused by an activity such as reading in bad light or working on a computer screen .  also called asthenopia 
eye surgeon  ||  noun a surgeon who specialises in operations on eyes 
eye test  ||  noun an examination of the inside of an eye to see if it is working correctly , and if the person needs glasses 
eyetooth  ||  noun a canine tooth , one of two pairs of pointed teeth next to the incisors ( note :  the plural is eyeteeth .  ) 

f abbr fahrenheit 
face  ||  noun the front part of the head , where the eyes , nose and mouth are placed  verb to have your face towards or to look towards something  please face the screen .  
face delivery  ||  noun a birth where the babys face appears first 
face lift  ||  , face - lifting operation  ||  noun a surgical operation to remove wrinkles on the face and neck 
face mask  ||  noun 1 .  a rubber mask that fits over the nose and mouth and is used to administer an anaesthetic 2 .  a piece of gauze which fits over the mouth and nose to prevent droplet infection 
face presentation  ||  noun a position of a baby in the uterus where the face will appear first at birth 
facet  ||  noun a flat surface on a bone 
facet syndrome  ||  noun a condition in which a joint in the vertebrae becomes dislocated 
facial  ||  adjective relating to , or appearing on , the face  the psychiatrist examined the patients facial expression .  
facial artery  ||  noun an artery which branches off the external carotid into the face and mouth 
facial bone  ||  noun one of the fourteen bones which form the face comment :  the bones which make up the face are :  two maxillae forming the upper jaw ; two nasal bones forming the top part of the nose ; two lacrimal bones on the inside of the orbit near the nose ; two zygomatic or malar bones forming the sides of the cheeks ; two palatine bones forming the back part of the top of the mouth ; two nasal conchae or turbinate bones which form the sides of the nasal cavity ; the mandible or lower jaw ; and the vomer in the centre of the nasal septum .  
facial nerve  ||  noun the seventh cranial nerve , which governs the muscles of the face , the taste buds on the front of the tongue and the salivary and lacrimal glands 
facial paralysis  ||  noun same as bells palsy 
facial vein  ||  noun a vein which drains down the side of the face into the internal jugular vein 
 - facient  ||  suffix making or causing  abortifacient 
facies  ||  noun someones facial appearance , used as a guide to diagnosis 
facilitation  ||  noun an act where several slight stimuli help a neurone to be activated 
facilities  ||  plural noun something such as equipment , accommodation , treatment or help that is provided for people who need them  the provision of aftercare facilities 
factor  ||  noun 1 .  something which has an influence or which makes something else take place 2 .  a substance , variously numbered , e.g. factor i , factor ii , in the plasma , which makes the blood coagulate when a blood vessel is injured 
factor ii  ||  same as prothrombin 
factor ix  ||  noun a protein in plasma which promotes the clotting of blood and is lacking in people with haemophilia b .  also called christmas factor 
factor viii  ||  noun a protein in plasma which promotes the clotting of blood and is lacking in people with haemophilia a 
factor xi  ||  noun a protein in plasma which promotes the clotting of blood and is lacking in people with haemophilia c 
factor xii  ||  noun a protein in plasma which promotes the clotting of blood and is lacking in some people with haemophilia .  also called hageman factor 
faculty  ||  noun the ability to do something 
fade away  ||  verb to be in the process of dying ( informal ) 
faecal  ||  adjective referring to faeces 
faecal impaction  ||  noun a condition in which a hardened mass of faeces stays in the rectum 
faecal incontinence  ||  noun an inability to control the bowel movements 
faecalith  ||  noun same as coprolith 
faecal matter  ||  noun solid waste matter from the bowels 
faeces  ||  plural noun solid waste matter passed from the bowels through the anus .  also called stools , bowel movement ( note :  for other terms referring to faeces , see words beginning with sterco -  .  ) 
fahrenheit  ||  , fahrenheit scale  ||  noun a scale of temperatures where the freezing and boiling points of water are 32° and 212° under standard atmospheric pressure ( note :  used in the us , but less common in the uk .  usually written as an f after the degree sign :  32°f ( say :  ‘thirty - two degrees fahrenheit’ ) .  ) comment :  to convert degrees fahrenheit into degrees celsius , subtract 32 and divide the remainder by 1 . 8 .  
fail  ||  verb 1 .  not to be successful in doing something  the doctor failed to see the symptoms .   she has failed her pharmacy exams .   he failed his medical and was rejected by the police force .  2 .  to become weaker and less likely to recover 
failing  ||  adjective weakening , or becoming closer to death 
failure to thrive  ||  noun same as marasmus 
faint  ||  verb to stop being conscious for a short time and , usually , fall down  noun a loss of consciousness for a short period , caused by a temporary reduction in the blood flow to the brain 
fainting fit  ||  , fainting spell  ||  noun same as syncope  she often had fainting fits when she was dieting .  
fairbanks’ splint  ||  noun a special splint used for correcting erbs palsy 
faith healing  ||  noun the treatment of pain or illness by a person who prays and may also lay his or her hands on the patient 
falciform  ||  adjective in the shape of a sickle 
falciform ligament  ||  noun a piece of tissue which separates the two lobes of the liver and attaches it to the diaphragm 
fall  ||  verb  to fall pregnant , to fall for a baby to become pregnant 
fall asleep  ||  verb to go to sleep 
fallen arches  ||  plural noun a condition in which the arches in the sole of the foot are not high 
fall ill  ||  verb to get ill or to start to have an illness  he fell ill while on holiday and had to be flown home .  
fallopian tube  ||  noun one of two tubes which connect the ovaries to the uterus .  see illustration at urogenital system ( female ) in supplement .  also called oviduct , salpinx ( note :  for other terms referring to fallopian tubes , see words beginning with salping , salpingo -  .  ) [described 1561 .  after gabriele fallopio ( 1523–63 ) , italian man of medicine .  he was professor of surgery and anatomy at padua , where he was also professor of botany . ] 
comment :  once a month , ova ( unfertilised eggs ) leave the ovaries and move down the fallopian tubes to the uterus .  at the point where the fallopian tubes join the uterus an ovum may be fertilised by a sperm cell .  sometimes fertilisation and development of the embryo take place in the fallopian tube itself .  this is called an ectopic pregnancy , and can be life - threatening if not detected early .  
fallots tetralogy  ||  noun same as tetralogy of fallot [described 1888 .  after etienne - louis arthur fallot ( 1850– 1911 ) , professor of hygiene and legal medicine at marseilles , france . ] 
false  ||  adjective not true or not real 
false pains  ||  plural noun pains which appear to be labour pains but are not 
false pregnancy  ||  noun a condition in which a woman believes wrongly that she is pregnant and displays symptoms and signs of pregnancy 
false rib  ||  noun one of the bottom five ribs on each side which are not directly attached to the breastbone 
false teeth  ||  plural noun dentures , artificial teeth made of plastic , which fit in the mouth and take the place of teeth which have been extracted 
false vocal cords  ||  plural noun same as vestibular folds 
falx  ||  , falx cerebri  ||  noun a fold of the dura mater between the two hemispheres of the cerebrum 
familial  ||  adjective referring to a family 
familial adenomatous polyposis  ||  noun a hereditary disorder where polyps develop in the small intestine .  abbr fap 
familial disorder  ||  noun a hereditary disorder which affects several members of the same family 
family  ||  noun a group of people who are related to each other , especially mother , father and children 
family doctor  ||  noun a general practitioner 
family planning  ||  noun the use of contraception to control the number of children in a family 
family planning clinic  ||  noun a clinic which gives advice on contraception 
family therapy  ||  noun a type of psychotherapy where members of the family of a person with a disorder meet a therapist to discuss the condition and try to come to terms with it 
famotidine  ||  noun a histamine which reduces the secretion of gastric acid and is used to treat ulcers 
fanconi syndrome  ||  noun a kidney disorder where amino acids are present in the urine [described 1927 .  after guido fanconi ( b . 1892 ) , professor of paediatrics at the university of zurich , switzerland . ] 
fantasise  ||  , fantasize verb to imagine that things have happened 
fantasy  ||  noun a series of imaginary events which someone believes really took place fap abbr familial adenomatous polyposis 
farcy  ||  noun a form of glanders which affects the lymph nodes 
farinaceous  ||  adjective referring to flour , or containing starch 
farmers lung  ||  noun a type of asthma caused by an allergy to rotting hay 
fas abbr fetal alcohol syndrome 
fascia  ||  noun fibrous tissue covering a muscle or an organ ( note :  the plural is fasciae .  ) 
fascia lata  ||  noun a wide sheet of tissue covering the thigh muscles 
fasciculation  ||  noun small muscle movements which appear as trembling skin 
fasciculus  ||  noun a bundle of nerve fibres ( note :  the plural is fasciculi .  ) 
fasciitis  ||  noun an inflammation of the connective tissue between muscles or around organs 
fascioliasis  ||  noun a disease caused by parasitic liver flukes 
fasciolopsis  ||  noun a type of liver fluke , often found in the far east , which is transmitted to humans through contaminated waterplants 
fast  ||  noun a period of going without food , e.g.  to lose weight or for religious reasons  verb to go without food  the patient should fast from midnight of the night before an operation .  
fastigium  ||  noun the highest temperature during a bout of fever 
fat  ||  adjective big and round in the body  you ought to eat less – you’re getting too fat . ( note :  fatter – fattest )  noun 1 .  a white oily substance in the body , which stores energy and protects the body against cold 2 .  a type of food which supplies protein and vitamins a and d , especially that part of meat which is white , and solid substances like lard or butter produced from animals and used for cooking , or liquid substances like oil  if you don’t like the fat on the meat , cut it off .   fry the eggs in some fat .  ( note :  fat has no plural when it means the substance ; the plural fats is used to mean different types of fat .  for other terms referring to fats , see also lipid and words beginning with steato -  .  ) comment :  fat is a necessary part of the diet because of the vitamins and energy - giving calories which it contains .  fat in the diet comes from either animal fats or vegetable fats .  animal fats such as butter , fat meat or cream , are saturated fatty acids .  it is believed that the intake of unsaturated and polyunsaturated fats , mainly vegetable fats and oils , and fish oil , in the diet , rather than animal fats , helps keep down the level of cholesterol in the blood and so lessens the risk of atherosclerosis .  a low - fat diet does not always help to reduce body weight .  
fatal  ||  adjective causing or resulting in death  he had a fatal accident .   cases of bee stings are rarely fatal .  
fatality  ||  noun a death as the result of something other than natural causes  there were three fatalities during the flooding .  
fatally  ||  adverb in a way which causes death  his heart was fatally weakened by the lung disease .  
father  ||  noun a biological or adoptive male parent 
fatigue  ||  noun very great tiredness  verb to tire someone out  he was fatigued by the hard work .  
fatigue fracture  ||  noun  stress fracture 
fat - soluble  ||  adjective able to dissolve in fat  vitamin d is fat - soluble .  
fatty  ||  adjective containing fat 
fatty acid  ||  noun an organic acid belonging to a group that occurs naturally as fats , oils and waxes .   essential fatty acid 
fatty degeneration  ||  noun same as adipose degeneration 
fauces  ||  noun an opening between the tonsils at the back of the throat , leading to the pharynx 
favism  ||  noun a type of inherited anaemia caused by an allergy to beans 
favus  ||  noun a highly contagious type of ringworm caused by a fungus which attacks the scalp 
fda abbr us food and drug administration 
fear  ||  noun a state where a person is afraid of something  fear of flying 
febricula  ||  noun a low fever 
febrifuge  ||  noun a drug which prevents or lowers a fever , e.g.  aspirin  adjective preventing or lowering fever 
febrile  ||  adjective referring to a fever , or caused by a fever 
febrile convulsion  ||  noun a convulsion in a child , lasting a short time , associated with a fever 
febrile disease  ||  noun a disease which is accompanied by fever 
fecal  ||  adjective us same as faecal 
fecundation  ||  noun the act of bringing male and female reproductive matter together .  also called fertilisation 
feeble  ||  adjective very weak 
feed  ||  verb to give food to someone  he has to be fed with a spoon .   the baby has reached the stage when she can feed herself . ( note :  feeding – fed ) 
feed back  ||  verb to give information or comments on something that has been done  the patients’ responses were fed back to the students .  
feedback  ||  noun 1 .  information or comments about something which has been done  the initial feedback from patients on the new service was encouraging .  2 .  the linking of the result of an action back to the action itself 
feeding  ||  noun the action of giving someone something to eat .   breast feeding , bottle feeding , intravenous feeding 
feeding cup  ||  noun a special cup with a spout , used for feeding people who cannot feed themselves 
feel  ||  verb 1 .  to touch someone or something , usually with your fingers  the midwife felt the abdomen gently .   to feel someones pulse to establish someones pulse rate , usually by holding the inner wrist 2 .  to give a sensation  my skin feels hot and itchy .  3 .  to have a sensation  when she got the results of her test , she felt relieved .   he felt ill after eating the fish .  4 .  to believe or think something  the doctor feels the patient is well enough to be moved out of intensive care .  ( note :  feeling – felt ) 
feeling  ||  noun 1 .  a sensation  a prickling feeling 2 .  an emotional state or attitude to something 
fehlings solution  ||  noun a solution used in fehlings test to detect sugar in urine [described 1848 .  after hermann christian von fehling ( 1812–85 ) , professor of chemistry at stuttgart , germany . ] 
fehlings test  ||  noun a test for the presence of aldehydes and sugars in a biological sample by means of fehlings solution 
felon  ||  noun same as whitlow 
feltys syndrome  ||  noun a condition , associated with rheumatoid arthritis , in which the spleen is enlarged and the number of white blood cells increases [described 1924 .  after augustus roi felty ( 1895– 1963 ) , physician at hartford hospital , connecticut , usa . ] 
female condom  ||  noun a rubber sheath inserted into the vagina before intercourse , covering the walls of the vagina and the cervix 
female sex hormone  ||  noun same as oestrogen 
feminisation  ||  , feminization noun the development of female characteristics in a male 
femora  ||  plural of femur 
femoral  ||  adjective referring to the femur or to the thigh 
femoral artery  ||  noun a continuation of the external iliac artery , which runs down the front of the thigh and then crosses to the back of the thigh 
femoral canal  ||  noun the inner tube of the sheath surrounding the femoral artery and vein 
femoral head  ||  noun the head of the femur , the rounded projecting end part of the thigh bone which joins the acetabulum at the hip 
femoral hernia  ||  noun a hernia of the bowel at the top of the thigh 
femoral neck  ||  noun the narrow part between the head and the diaphysis of the femur .  also called neck of the femur 
femoral nerve  ||  noun a nerve which governs the muscle at the front of the thigh 
femoral pulse  ||  noun a pulse taken in the groin 
femoral triangle  ||  noun a slight hollow in the groin which contains the femoral vessels and nerve .  also called scarpas triangle 
femoral vein  ||  noun a vein running up the upper leg , a continuation of the popliteal vein 
femoris  ||  noun  rectus femoris 
femur  ||  noun the bone in the top part of the leg which joins the acetabulum at the hip and the tibia at the knee .  also called thighbone .  see illustration at pelvis in supplement ( note :  the plural is femora .  ) 
 - fen  ||  suffix used in names of non - steroidal anti - inflammatory drugs  ibuprofen 
fenestra  ||  noun a small opening in the ear 
fenestra ovalis  ||  noun same as oval window 
fenestra rotunda  ||  noun same as round window 
fenestration  ||  noun a surgical operation to relieve deafness by making a small opening in the inner ear 
fenoprofen  ||  noun a non - steroidal , anti - inflammatory drug that is used to manage the pain of arthritis 
fentanyl  ||  noun a narcotic drug that is a powerful painkiller 
fermentation  ||  noun a process where carbohydrates are broken down by enzymes from yeast and produce alcohol .  also called zymosis 
ferric  ||  adjective containing iron with a valency of three 
ferritin  ||  noun a protein found in the liver that binds reversibly to iron and stores it for later use in making haemoglobin in red blood cells 
ferrous  ||  adjective containing iron with a valency of two 
ferrous sulphate  ||  noun a white or pale green iron salt that is used in the treatment of iron - deficient anaemia 
ferrule  ||  noun a metal or rubber cap or ring that strengthens and protects the lower end of a crutch or walking stick  verb to fit a ferrule onto a crutch or walking stick 
fertile  ||  adjective able to produce children .  opposite sterile 
fertilisation  ||  , fertilization noun the joining of an ovum and a sperm to form a zygote and so start the development of an embryo 
fertilise  ||  , fertilize verb ( of a sperm ) to join with an ovum 
fertility  ||  noun the fact of being fertile .  opposite sterility 
fertility drug  ||  noun a drug that stimulates ovulation , given to women undergoing in vitro fertilisation 
fertility rate  ||  noun the number of births per year calculated per 1000 females aged between 15 and 44 
fess abbr functional endoscopic sinus surgery 
fester  ||  verb ( of an infected wound ) to become inflamed and produce pus  his legs were covered with festering sores .  
festination  ||  noun a way of walking in which a person takes short steps , seen in people who have parkinsons disease 
fetal  ||  adjective referring to a fetus 
fetal alcohol syndrome  ||  noun damage caused to the fetus by alcohol in the blood of the mother , which affects the growth of the embryo , including its facial and brain development .  abbr fas 
fetal distress  ||  noun a condition , e.g.  a heart or respiratory problem , in which a fetus may not survive if the condition is not monitored and corrected 
fetal dystocia  ||  noun a difficult childbirth caused by a malformation or malpresentation of the fetus 
fetal heart  ||  noun the heart of the fetus 
fetalis  ||   erythroblastosis fetalis 
fetal monitor  ||  noun an electronic device which monitors the fetus in the uterus 
fetal position  ||  noun a position where a person lies curled up on his or her side , like a fetus in the uterus 
fetishism  ||  , fetichism noun a psychological disorder in which someone gets sexual satisfaction from touching objects 
fetishist  ||  , fetichist noun a person who has fetishism 
feto -  ||  prefix fetus 
fetoprotein  ||  noun  alphafetoprotein 
fetor  ||  noun a bad smell 
fetoscope  ||  noun a stethoscope used in fetoscopy 
fetoscopy  ||  noun an examination of a fetus inside the uterus , taking blood samples to diagnose blood disorders 
fetus  ||  noun an unborn baby from two months after conception until birth , before which it is called an embryo 
fev abbr forced expiratory volume 
fever  ||  noun 1 .  a rise in body temperature  she is running a slight fever .   you must stay in bed until the fever has gone down .  2 .  a condition when the temperature of the body is higher than usual  also called pyrexia comment :  average oral body temperature is about 98 . 6°f or 37°c and rectal temperature is about 99°f or 37 . 2°c .  a fever often makes the patient feel cold , and is accompanied by pains in the joints .  most fevers are caused by infections .  infections which result in fever include cat - scratch fever , dengue , malaria , meningitis , psittacosis , q fever , rheumatic fever , rocky mountain spotted fever , scarlet fever , septicaemia , typhoid fever , typhus and yellow fever .  
fever blister  ||  noun same as fever sore 
feverfew  ||  noun a herb , formerly used to reduce fevers , but now used to relieve migraine 
feverish  ||  adjective with a fever  he felt feverish and took an aspirin .   she is in bed with a feverish chill .  
fever sore  ||  noun a cold sore or burning sore , usually on the lips 
fiber  ||  noun us same as fibre 
fibr -  ||  prefix referring to fibres , fibrous ( used before vowels ) 
 - fibrate  ||  suffix used in names of lipid - lowering drugs 
fibre  ||  noun 1 .  a structure in the body shaped like a thread 2 .  same as dietary fibre 
fibre optics  ||  , fibreoptics noun the use of thin fibres which conduct light and images to examine internal organs 
fibrescope  ||  noun a device made of bundles of optical fibres which is passed into the body , used for examining internal organs 
fibril  ||  noun a very small fibre 
fibrillate  ||  verb to undergo rapid irregular uncontrolled contractions , or make the heart or muscles undergo this type of contraction 
fibrillating  ||  adjective with fluttering of a muscle  they applied a defibrillator to correct a fibrillating heartbeat .  
fibrillation  ||  noun the fluttering of a muscle ‘cardiovascular effects may include atrial arrhythmias but at 30°c there is the possibility of spontaneous ventricular fibrillation’ [british journal of nursing] 
fibrin  ||  noun a protein produced by fibrinogen , which helps make blood coagulate comment :  removal of fibrin from a blood sample is called defibrination .  
fibrin foam  ||  noun a white material made artificially from fibrinogen , used to prevent bleeding 
fibrinogen  ||  noun a substance in blood plasma which produces fibrin when activated by thrombin 
fibrinolysin  ||  noun an enzyme which digests fibrin .  also called plasmin 
fibrinolysis  ||  noun the removal of blood clots from the system by the action of fibrinolysin on fibrin .  also called thrombolysis 
fibrinolytic  ||  adjective referring to fibrinolysis  fibrinolytic drugs also called thrombolytic 
fibro -  ||  prefix referring to fibres 
fibroadenoma  ||  noun a benign tumour formed of fibrous and glandular tissue 
fibroblast  ||  noun a long flat cell found in connective tissue , which develops into collagen 
fibrocartilage  ||  noun cartilage and fibrous tissue combined comment :  fibrocartilage is found in the discs of the spine .  it is elastic like cartilage and pliable like fibre .  
fibrochondritis  ||  noun inflammation of the fibrocartilage 
fibrocyst  ||  noun a benign tumour of fibrous tissue 
fibrocystic  ||  adjective referring to a fibrocyst 
fibrocystic disease  ||  , fibrocystic disease of the pancreas  ||  noun same as cystic fibrosis 
fibrocyte  ||  noun a cell which derives from a fibroblast and is found in connective tissue 
fibroelastosis  ||  noun a deformed growth of the elastic fibres , especially in the ventricles of the heart 
fibroid  ||  adjective like fibre  noun same as fibroid tumour 
fibroid degeneration  ||  noun the change of healthy tissue to fibrous tissue , e.g.  as in cirrhosis of the liver 
fibroid tumour  ||  noun a benign tumour in the muscle fibres of the uterus .  also called uterine fibroid , fibromyoma 
fibroma  ||  noun a small benign tumour formed in connective tissue 
fibromuscular  ||  adjective referring to fibrous tissue and muscular tissue 
fibromyoma  ||  noun same as fibroid tumour 
fibroplasia  ||  noun  retrolental fibroplasia 
fibrosa  ||   osteitis fibrosa cystica 
fibrosarcoma  ||  noun a malignant tumour of the connective tissue , most common in the legs 
fibrosis  ||  noun the process of replacing damaged tissue by scar tissue 
fibrositis  ||  noun a painful inflammation of the fibrous tissue which surrounds muscles and joints , especially the muscles of the back 
fibrous  ||  adjective made of fibres , or like fibre 
fibrous capsule  ||  noun 
fibrous tissue surrounding a kidney .  also called renal capsule 
fibrous joint  ||  noun a joint where fibrous tissue holds two bones together so that they cannot move , as in the bones of the skull 
fibrous pericardium  ||  noun the outer part of the pericardium which surrounds the heart , and is attached to the main blood vessels 
fibrous tissue  ||  noun strong white tissue which makes tendons and ligaments and also scar tissue 
fibula  ||  noun the thinner of the two bones in the lower leg between the knee and the ankle .  compare tibia ( note :  the plural is fibulae .  ) 
fibular  ||  adjective referring to the fibula 
field  ||  noun an area of interest  he specialises in the field of community medicine .   don’t see that specialist with your breathing problems – his field is obstetrics .  
field of vision  ||  noun same as visual field 
fight or flight reaction  ||  noun the theory that an organism which is faced with a threat reacts either by preparing to fight or to escape 
fil -  ||  prefix referring to a thread 
filament  ||  noun a long thin structure like a thread 
filamentous  ||  adjective like a thread 
filaria  ||  noun a thin parasitic worm which is found especially in the lymph system , and is passed to humans by mosquitoes ( note :  the plural is filariae .  ) comment :  infestation with filariae in the lymph system causes elephantiasis .  
filariasis  ||  noun a tropical disease caused by parasitic threadworms in the lymph system , transmitted by mosquito bites 
filiform  ||  adjective shaped like a thread 
filiform papillae  ||  plural noun papillae on the tongue which are shaped like threads , and have no taste buds 
filipuncture  ||  noun the procedure of putting a wire into an aneurysm to cause blood clotting 
fill  ||  verb  to fill a tooth to put metal into a hole in a tooth after it has been drilled 
filling  ||  noun 1 .  a surgical operation carried out by a dentist to fill a hole in a tooth with amalgam 2 .  amalgam , metallic mixture put into a hole in a tooth by a dentist 
film  ||  noun a very thin layer of a substance covering a surface 
filter  ||  noun a piece of paper or cloth through which a liquid is passed to remove any solid substances in it  verb to pass a liquid through a membrane , piece of paper or cloth to remove solid substances  impurities are filtered from the blood by the kidneys .  
filtrate  ||  noun a substance which has passed through a filter 
filtration  ||  noun the action of passing a liquid through a filter 
filum  ||  noun a structure which is shaped like a thread 
filum terminale  ||  noun the thin end section of the pia mater in the spinal cord 
fim abbr functional independence measure 
fimbria  ||  noun a fringe , especially the fringe of hair - like processes at the end of a fallopian tube near the ovaries ( note :  the plural is fimbriae .  ) 
final common pathway  ||  noun linked neurones which take all impulses from the central nervous system to a muscle 
fine  ||  adjective 1 .  healthy  he was ill last week , but hes feeling fine now .  2 .  referring to something such as hair or thread which is very thin  there is a growth of fine hair on the back of her neck .   fine sutures are used for delicate operations .  
finger  ||  noun one of the five parts at the end of the hand , but usually not including the thumb ( note :  the names of the fingers are :  little finger , third finger or ring finger , middle finger , forefinger or index finger .  ) comment :  each finger is formed of three finger bones ( the phalanges ) , but the thumb has only two .  
fingernail  ||  noun a hard thin growth covering the end of a finger  ridged and damaged fingernails 
finger - nose test  ||  noun a test of coordination , where the person is asked to close their eyes , stretch out their arm and then touch their nose with their index finger 
fingerprint  ||  noun a mark left by a finger when something is touched .   genetic 
fingerstall  ||  noun a cover for an infected finger , attached to the hand with strings 
firemans lift  ||  noun a way of carrying an injured person by putting their body over one shoulder 
firm  ||  noun a group of doctors and consultants in a hospital , especially one to which a trainee doctor is attached during clinical studies ( informal ) 
first aid  ||  noun help given by a non - medical person to someone who is suddenly ill or injured before full - scale medical treatment can be given  she gave him first aid in the street until the ambulance arrived .  
first - aider  ||  noun a person who gives first aid to someone who is suddenly ill or injured 
first - aid kit  ||  noun a box with bandages and dressings kept ready to be used in an emergency 
first - aid post  ||  , first - aid station  ||  noun a place where injured people can be taken for immediate care 
first - degree burn  ||  noun a former classification of the severity of a burn , where the skin turns red 
first - degree haemorrhoids  ||  plural noun haemorrhoids which remain in the rectum 
first - degree relative  ||  noun a relative with whom an individual shares 50% of their genes , e.g.  a father , mother , sibling or child 
first - ever stroke  ||  noun a stroke which someone has for the first time in his or her life 
first intention  ||  noun the healing of a clean wound where the tissue forms again rapidly and no prominent scar is left 
first - level nurse  ||  , first - level registered nurse  ||  noun a nurse who has passed qualifying examinations , is registered as such with the nursing and midwifery council and can act in an independent decision - making role .  compare second - level nurse 
fissile  ||  adjective able to split or be split 
fission  ||  noun the act of dividing into two or more parts 
fissure  ||  noun a crack or groove in the skin , tissue or an organ  horizontal and oblique fissures grooves between the lobes of the lungs .  see illustration at lungs in supplement 
fist  ||  noun a hand which is tightly closed 
fistula  ||  noun a passage or opening which has been made unusually between two organs , often near the rectum or anus 
fistula in ano  ||  noun same as anal fistula 
fit  ||  adjective strong and physically healthy  she exercises every day to keep fit .   the doctors decided the patient was not fit for surgery .  ( note :  fitter – fittest )  he isn’t fit enough to work he is still too ill to work  noun a sudden attack of a disorder , especially convulsions and epilepsy  she had a fit of coughing .   he had an epileptic fit .   the baby had a series of fits .   verb 1 .  to attach an appliance correctly  the surgeons fitted the artificial hand to the patients arm or fitted the patient with an artificial hand .  2 .  to provide a piece of equipment for someone to wear  she was fitted with temporary support .  3 .  to have convulsions  the patient has fitted twice .  ( note :  fitting – fitted .  note also :  you fit someone with an appliance .  ) 
fitness  ||  noun the fact of being strong and healthy  being in the football team demands a high level of physical fitness .   he had to pass a fitness test to join the police force .  
fixated  ||  adjective referring to a person who has too close an attachment to another person , often to a parent 
fixation  ||  noun a psychological disorder where a person does not develop beyond a particular stage 
fixative  ||  noun a chemical used in the preparation of samples on slides 
fixator  ||  noun a metal rod placed through a bone to keep a part of the body rigid 
fixed oil  ||  noun 1 .  an oil which is liquid at 20°c 2 .  liquid fats , especially those used as food 
flab  ||  noun soft fat flesh ( informal )  hes doing exercises to try to fight the flab .  
flabby  ||  adjective with soft flesh  she has got flabby from sitting at her desk all day .  
flaccid  ||  adjective soft or flabby 
flaccidity  ||  noun the state of being flaccid 
flagellate  ||  noun a type of parasitic protozoan which uses whip - like hairs to swim , e.g.  leishmania 
flagellum  ||  noun a tiny growth on a microorganism , shaped like a whip ( note :  the plural is flagella .  ) 
flagyl  ||  a trade name for metronidazole 
flail  ||  verb to thrash around with uncontrollable or violent movements , particularly of the arms 
flail chest  ||  noun a condition in which the chest is not stable , because several ribs have been broken 
flake  ||  noun a thin piece of tissue  dandruff is formed of flakes of dead skin on the scalp .  
flake fracture  ||  noun a fracture where thin pieces of bone come off 
flake off  ||  verb to fall off as flakes 
flap  ||  noun a flat piece attached to something , especially a piece of skin or tissue still attached to the body at one side and used in grafts 
flare  ||  noun red colouring of the skin at an infected spot or in urticaria 
flashback  ||  noun a repeated and very vivid memory of a traumatic event 
flash burn  ||  noun a burn caused when a body part is briefly exposed to a source of intense heat 
flat foot  ||  , flat feet  ||  noun a condition in which the soles of the feet lie flat on the ground instead of being arched as usual .  also called pes planus 
flatline  ||  verb to fail to show on a monitor any of the electrical currents associated with heart or brain activity  noun a monitor readout on an eeg or ecg indicating total cessation of brain or cardiac activity , respectively 
flatulence  ||  noun gas or air which collects in the stomach or intestines causing discomfort comment :  flatulence is generally caused by indigestion , but can be made worse if the person swallows air ( aerophagy ) .  
flatulent  ||  adjective having flatulence , or caused by flatulence 
flatus  ||  noun air and gas which collects in the intestines and is painful 
flatworm  ||  noun any of several types of parasitic worm with a flat body , e.g.  a tapeworm .  compare roundworm 
flea  ||  noun a tiny insect which sucks blood and is a parasite on animals and humans comment :  fleas can transmit disease , most especially bubonic plague which is transmitted by infected rat fleas .  
flecainide  ||  noun a drug that helps to correct an irregular heartbeat 
flesh  ||  noun tissue containing blood , forming the part of the body which is not skin , bone or organs 
flesh wound  ||  noun a wound which only affects the fleshy part of the body  she had a flesh wound in her leg .  
fleshy  ||  adjective 1 .  made of flesh 2 .  fat 
flex  ||  verb to bend something  to flex a joint to use a muscle to make a joint bend 
flexibilitas cerea  ||  noun a condition in which , if someones arms or legs are moved , they remain in that set position for some time 
flexion  ||  noun the act of bending a joint 
flexners bacillus  ||  noun a bacterium which causes bacillary dysentery 
flexor  ||  , flexor muscle  ||  noun a muscle which makes a joint bend .  compare extensor 
flexure  ||  noun 1 .  a bend in an organ 2 .  a fold in the skin 
floaters  ||  plural noun same as muscae volitantes 
floating kidney  ||  noun same as nephroptosis 
floating rib  ||  noun one of the two lowest ribs on each side , which are not attached to the breastbone 
floccillation  ||  noun the action of constantly touching the bedclothes , a sign that someone is approaching death 
floccitation  ||  noun same as carphology 
flooding  ||  noun same as menorrhagia 
floppy baby syndrome  ||  noun same as amyotonia congenita 
flora  ||  noun bacteria which exist in a particular part of the body 
florid  ||  adjective with an unhealthily glowing pink or red complexion 
floss  ||  noun same as dental floss  verb to clean the teeth with dental floss 
flow  ||  noun 1 .  a movement of liquid or gas  they used a tourniquet to try to stop the flow of blood .  2 .  the amount of liquid or gas which is moving  the meter measures the flow of water through the pipe .  
flowmeter  ||  noun a meter attached to a pipe , e.g.  as in anaesthetic equipment , to measure the speed at which a liquid or gas moves in the pipe 
flu  ||  noun 1 .  same as influenza 2 .  a very bad cold ( informal ) ( note :  sometimes written ’flu to show it is a short form of influenza .  ) 
flucloxacillin  ||  noun a drug related to penicillin and effective against streptococcal infections and pneumonia 
fluconazole  ||  noun a drug used to treat fungal infections such as candidiasis 
fluctuation  ||  noun the feeling of movement of liquid inside part of the body or inside a cyst when pressed by the fingers 
fluid  ||  noun 1 .  a liquid 2 .  any gas , liquid or powder which flows 
fluid balance  ||  noun the maintenance of the balance of fluids in the body during dialysis or other treatment 
fluke  ||  noun a parasitic flatworm which settles inside the liver , in the bloodstream and in other parts of the body 
flunitrazepam  ||  noun a tranquilliser that , because of its association with ‘date rape’ cases , is a controlled drug in the uk 
fluorescence  ||  noun the sending out of light from a substance which is receiving radiation 
fluorescent  ||  adjective referring to a substance which sends out light 
fluoridate  ||  verb to add fluoride to a substance , usually to drinking water , in order to help prevent tooth decay 
fluoride  ||  noun a chemical compound of fluorine and sodium , potassium or tin  fluoride toothpaste comment :  fluoride will reduce decay in teeth and is often added to drinking water or to toothpaste .  some people object to fluoridation and it is thought that too high a concentration , such as that achieved by highly fluoridated water and the use of a highly fluoridated toothpaste , may discolour the teeth of children .  
fluorine  ||  noun a chemical element found in bones and teeth ( note :  the chemical symbol is f .  ) 
fluoroscope  ||  noun an apparatus which projects an x - ray image of a part of the body onto a screen , so that the part of the body can be examined as it moves 
fluoroscopy  ||  noun an examination of the body using x - rays projected onto a screen 
fluorosis  ||  noun a condition caused by excessive fluoride in drinking water comment :  at a low level , fluorosis causes discoloration of the teeth , and as the level of fluoride rises , ligaments can become calcified .  
fluoxetine  ||  noun a drug that increases serotonin in the brain and is used to treat anxiety and depression 
flush  ||  noun a red colour in the skin  verb 1 .  to wash a wound with liquid 2 .  ( of person ) to turn red 
flushed  ||  adjective with red skin , e.g.  due to heat , emotion or overeating  her face was flushed and she was breathing heavily .  
flutter  ||  , fluttering  ||  noun a rapid movement , especially of the atria of the heart , which is not controlled by impulses from the sinoatrial node 
flux  ||  noun an excessive production of liquid from the body 
focal  ||  adjective referring to a focus 
focal distance  ||  , focal length  ||  noun the distance between the lens of the eye and the point behind the lens where light is focused 
focal epilepsy  ||  noun epilepsy arising from a localised area of the brain 
focal myopathy  ||  noun destruction of muscle tissue caused by a substance injected in an intramuscular injection 
focus  ||  noun 1 .  the point where light rays converge through a lens 2 .  the centre of an infection ( note :  the plural is foci .  )  verb 1 .  to adjust a lens until an image is clear and sharp 2 .  to see clearly  he has difficulty in focusing on the object .  
focus group  ||  noun a discussion group of lay people brought together under professional guidance to discuss issues such as care 
foetal  ||  adjective another spelling of fetal ( note :  the spelling foetal is common in general use in british english , but the spelling fetal is the accepted international spelling for technical use .  ) 
foetor  ||  noun another spelling of fetor 
foetoscope  ||  noun another spelling of fetoscope 
foetoscopy  ||  noun another spelling of fetoscopy 
foetus  ||  noun another spelling of fetus ( note :  the spelling foetus is common in general use in british english , but the spelling fetus is the accepted international spelling for technical use .  ) 
folacin  ||  noun same as folic acid 
fold  ||  noun a part of the body which is bent so that it lies on top of another part 
folic acid  ||  noun a vitamin in the vitamin b complex found in milk , liver , yeast and green vegetables such as spinach , which is essential for creating new blood cells comment :  lack of folic acid can cause anaemia and neural tube disorders in the developing fetus .  it can also be caused by alcoholism .  
folie à deux  ||  noun a rare condition where a psychological disorder is communicated between two people who live together 
follicle  ||  noun a tiny hole or sac in the body comment :  an ovarian follicle goes through several stages in its development .  the first stage is called a primordial follicle , which then develops into a primary follicle and becomes a mature follicle by the sixth day of the period .  this follicle secretes oestrogen until the ovum has developed to the point when it can break out , leaving the corpus luteum behind .  
follicle - stimulating hormone  ||  noun a hormone produced by the pituitary gland which stimulates ova in the ovaries and sperm in the testes .  abbr fsh 
follicular  ||  , folliculate  ||  adjective referring to follicles 
follicular tumour  ||  noun a tumour in a follicle 
folliculin  ||  noun an oestrone , a type of oestrogen  she is undergoing folliculin treatment .  
folliculitis  ||  noun inflammation of the hair follicles , especially where hair has been shaved 
follow  ||  , follow up  ||  verb to check on someone who has been examined before in order to assess the progress of a disease or the results of treatment 
follow - up  ||  noun a check on someone who has been examined before ‘…length of follow - ups varied from three to 108 months .  thirteen patients were followed for less than one year , but the remainder were seen regularly for periods from one to nine years’ [new zealand medical journal] 
fomentation  ||  noun same as poultice 
fomites  ||  plural noun objects touched by someone with a communicable disease which can then be the means of passing on the disease to others 
fontanelle  ||  , fontanel noun the soft cartilage between the bony sections of a babys skull comment :  the fontanelles gradually harden over a period of months and by the age of 18 months the bones of the babys skull are usually solid .  
food allergen  ||  noun a substance in food which produces an allergy 
food allergy  ||  noun an allergy to a specific food such as nuts , which causes a severe reaction that may lead to life - threatening anaphylactic shock 
food canal  ||  noun the passage from the mouth to the rectum through which food passes and is digested 
food intolerance  ||  noun an adverse reaction to some foods such as oranges , eggs , tomatoes and strawberries 
food poisoning  ||  noun an illness caused by eating food which is contaminated with bacteria 
foot  ||  noun the end part of the leg on which a person stands comment :  the foot is formed of 26 bones :  14 phalanges in the toes , five metatarsals in the main part of the foot and seven tarsals in the heel .  
footpump  ||  noun a device to reduce the risk of post - operative deep - vein thrombosis by mechanical use of leg muscles 
foramen  ||  noun a natural opening inside the body , e.g.  the opening in a bone through which veins or nerves pass ( note :  the plural is foramina .  ) 
foramen magnum  ||  noun the hole at the bottom of the skull where the brain is joined to the spinal cord 
foramen ovale  ||  noun an opening between the two parts of the heart in a fetus comment :  the foramen ovale usually closes at birth , but if it stays open the blood from the veins can mix with the blood going to the arteries , causing cyanosis .  
foramina  ||  plural of foramen 
forced expiratory volume  ||  noun the maximum amount of air that can be expelled in a given time .  abbr fev 
force - feed  ||  verb to make someone swallow food against their will , e.g.  by using a tube to put it directly down their throat 
forceps  ||  noun a surgical instrument with handles like a pair of scissors , made in different sizes and with differently shaped ends , used for holding and pulling 
forceps delivery  ||  noun childbirth where the doctor uses forceps to help the baby out of the mothers uterus 
fore -  ||  prefix in front 
forearm  ||  noun the lower part of the arm from the elbow to the wrist 
forearm bones  ||  plural noun the ulna and the radius 
forebrain  ||  noun the front part of the brain in an embryo 
forefinger  ||  noun the first finger on the hand , next to the thumb 
foregut  ||  noun the front part of the gut in an embryo 
forehead  ||  noun the part of the face above the eyes 
foreign  ||  adjective 1 .  not belonging to your own country  foreign visitors  a foreign language 2 .  referring to something that is found where it does not naturally belong , especially something found in the human body that comes from a source outside the body  a foreign object  foreign matter 
foreign body  ||  noun a piece of material which is not part of the surrounding tissue and should not be there , e.g.  sand in a cut , dust in the eye or a pin which has been swallowed  the x - ray showed the presence of a foreign body .   swallowed foreign bodies something which should not have been swallowed , e.g.  a pin , coin or button 
foremilk  ||  noun the relatively low - fat milk with a high sugar content that is produced by a woman at the beginning of a breast feed 
forensic  ||  adjective relating to the use of science in solving criminal investigations or settling legal cases 
forensic medicine  ||  noun the branch of medical science concerned with finding solutions to crimes against people and which involves procedures such as conducting autopsies on murdered people or taking blood samples from clothes 
foreskin  ||  noun the skin covering the top of the penis , which can be removed by circumcision .  also called prepuce 
forewaters  ||  plural noun fluid which comes out of the vagina at the beginning of childbirth when the amnion bursts 
forgetful  ||  adjective referring to someone who often forgets things  she became very forgetful , and had to be looked after by her sister .  
forgetfulness  ||  noun a condition in which someone often forgets things  increasing forgetfulness is a sign of old age .  
form  ||  noun 1 .  shape 2 .  a piece of paper with blank spaces which you have to write in  you have to fill in a form when you are admitted to hospital .  3 .  a state or condition  in good form  hes in good form today he is very amusing , he is doing things well  verb to make or to be the main part of something  calcium is one the elements which form bones or bones are mainly formed of calcium .   an ulcer formed in his duodenum .   in diphtheria a membrane forms across the larynx .  
formaldehyde  ||  noun a gas with an unpleasant smell that is a strong disinfectant .  when dissolved in water to make formalin , it is also used to preserve medical specimens .  
formalin  ||  noun a solution of formaldehyde in water , used to preserve medical specimens 
formation  ||  noun the action of forming something  drinking milk helps the formation of bones .  
formication  ||  noun an itching feeling where the skin feels as if it were covered with insects 
formula  ||  noun 1 .  a way of indicating a chemical compound using letters and numbers , e.g.  h2so4 2 .  instructions on how to prepare a drug 3 .  uspowdered milk for babies ( note :  the plural is formulas or formulae .  ) 
formulary  ||  noun a book that lists medicines together with their formulae 
fornix  ||  noun an arch ( note :  the plural is fornices .  )  fornix of the vagina space between the cervix of the uterus and the vagina 
fornix cerebri  ||  noun a section of white matter in the brain between the hippocampus and the hypothalamus .  see illustration at brain in supplement 
fortification figures  ||  plural noun patterns of coloured light , seen as part of the aura before a migraine attack occurs 
foscarnet  ||  noun an antiviral drug administered by intravenous injection that is effective against herpesviruses that are resistant to acyclovir .  it is especially used for people with aids .  
fossa  ||  noun a shallow hollow in a bone or the skin 
foster children  ||  plural noun children brought up by people who are not their own parents 
foster parent  ||  noun a woman or man who brings up a child born to other parents 
fothergills operation  ||  noun a surgical operation to correct prolapse of the uterus [after w .  e .  fothergill ( 1865–1926 ) , british gynaecologist . ] 
foundation hospital  ||  noun in the uk , a proposed type of hospital that would be independent of its local health authority in financial matters 
fourchette  ||  noun a fold of skin at the back of the vulva 
fovea  ||  , fovea centralis  ||  noun a depression in the retina which is the point where the eye sees most clearly .  see illustration at eye in supplement 
fp10  ||  noun in the uk , an nhs prescription from a gp 
fracture  ||  verb 1 .  ( of bone ) to break  the tibia fractured in two places .  2 .  to break a bone  he fractured his wrist .   noun a break in a bone  rib fracture or fracture of a rib 
fractured  ||  adjective broken  he had a fractured skull .   she went to hospital to have her fractured leg reset .  
fragile  ||  adjective easily broken  elderly peoples bones are more fragile than those of adolescents .  
fragile - x syndrome  ||  noun a hereditary condition in which part of an x chromosome is constricted , causing mental impairment 
fragilitas  ||  noun fragility or brittleness 
fragilitas ossium  ||  noun a hereditary condition where the bones are brittle and break easily , similar to osteogenesis imperfecta 
frail  ||  adjective weak , easily broken  grandfather is getting frail , and we have to look after him all the time .   the babys bones are still very frail .  
framboesia  ||  noun same as yaws 
frame  ||  noun 1 .  the particular size and shape of someones body 2 .  a solid support for something .   walking frame , zimmer frame 
framework  ||  noun the main bones which make up the structure of part of the body 
framycetin  ||  noun an antibiotic 
fraternal twins  ||  plural noun same as dizygotic twins 
freckle  ||  noun a harmless small brownish patch on the skin that becomes more noticeable after exposure to the sun .  freckles are often found in people with fair hair .  also called lentigo  verb to mark something , or become marked with freckles 
freckled  ||  adjective with brown spots on the skin 
freeze  ||  verb to anaesthetise part of the body ( informal )  they froze my big toe to remove the nail .  
freeze dry  ||  verb to freeze something rapidly then dry it in a vacuum 
freeze drying  ||  noun a method of preserving food or tissue specimens by freezing rapidly and drying in a vacuum 
freibergs disease  ||  noun osteochondritis of the head of the second metatarsus [described 1914 .  after albert henry freiberg ( 1869–1940 ) , us surgeon . ] 
frei test  ||  noun a test for the venereal disease lymphogranuloma inguinale [described 1925 .  after wilhelm siegmund frei ( 1885–1943 ) , professor of dermatology at berlin , germany .  he settled in new york , usa . ] 
fremitus  ||  noun vibrations or trembling in part of someones body , felt by the doctors hand or heard through a stethoscope 
french letter  ||  noun  condom ( informal ) 
frenectomy  ||  noun an operation to remove a frenum 
frenkels exercises  ||  plural noun exercises for people who have locomotor ataxia , to teach coordination of the muscles and limbs 
frenotomy  ||  noun an operation to split a frenum 
frenum  ||  , frenulum  ||  noun a fold of mucous membrane under the tongue or by the clitoris 
frequency  ||  noun 1 .  the number of times something takes place in a given time  the frequency of micturition 2 .  the rate of vibration in oscillations 
fresh air  ||  noun open air  they came out of the hospital into the fresh air .  
fresh frozen plasma  ||  noun plasma made from freshly donated blood , and kept frozen 
fretful  ||  adjective referring to a baby that cries , cannot sleep or seems unhappy 
freudian  ||  adjective understandable in terms of freuds theories , especially with regard to human sexuality  noun someone who is influenced by or follows freuds theories or methods of psychoanalysis 
friable  ||  adjective easily broken up into small pieces 
friars balsam  ||  noun a mixture of various plant oils , including benzoin and balsam , which can be inhaled as a vapour to relieve bronchitis or congestion 
friction  ||  noun the rubbing together of two surfaces 
friction fremitus  ||  noun a scratching sensation felt when the hand is placed on the chest of someone who has pericarditis 
friction murmur  ||  noun the sound of two serous membranes rubbing together , heard with a stethoscope in someone who has pericarditis or pleurisy 
friedländers bacillus  ||  noun the bacterium klebsiella pneumoniae which can cause pneumonia [described 1882 .  after carl friedländer ( 1847–87 ) , pathologist at the friedrichshain hospital , berlin , germany . ] 
friedmans test  ||  noun a test for pregnancy [after maurice h .  friedman ( b .  1903 ) , us physician . ] 
friedreichs ataxia  ||  noun an inherited nervous disease which affects the spinal cord and is associated with club foot , an unsteady walk and speech difficulties .  also called dystrophia adiposogenitalis [described 1863 .  after nicholaus friedreich ( 1825–82 ) , professor of pathological anatomy at würzburg , later professor of pathology and therapy at heidelberg , germany . ] 
frigidity  ||  noun the fact of being unable to experience orgasm , sexual pleasure or sexual desire 
fringe medicine  ||  noun types of medical practice which are not usually taught in medical schools , e.g.  homeopathy or acupuncture ( informal ) 
frog plaster  ||  noun a plaster cast made to keep the legs in an open position after an operation to correct a dislocated hip 
fröhlichs syndrome  ||  noun a condition in which someone becomes obese and the genital system does not develop , caused by an adenoma of the pituitary gland [described 1901 .  after alfred fröhlich ( 1871– 1953 ) , professor of pharmacology at the university of vienna , austria . ] 
frontal  ||  adjective referring to the forehead or to the front of the head .  opposite 
occipital 
frontal bone  ||  noun a bone forming the front of the upper part of the skull behind the forehead 
frontal lobe  ||  noun the front lobe of each cerebral hemisphere 
frontal lobotomy  ||  noun formerly , a surgical operation on the brain to treat mental illness by removing part of the frontal lobe 
frontal sinus  ||  noun one of two sinuses in the front of the face above the eyes and near the nose 
front passage  ||  ( informal ) 1 .  same as urethra 2 .  same as vagina 
frostbite  ||  noun an injury caused by very severe cold which freezes tissue 
frostbitten  ||  adjective having frostbite comment :  in very cold conditions , the outside tissue of the fingers , toes , ears and nose can freeze , becoming white and numb .  thawing of frostbitten tissue can be very painful and must be done very slowly .  severe cases of frostbite may require amputation because the tissue has died and gangrene has set in .  
frozen shoulder  ||  noun stiffness and pain in the shoulder , caused by inflammation of the membranes of the shoulder joint after injury or a period of immobility , when deposits may form in the tendons 
frozen watchfulness  ||  noun an expression of petrified fear on a childs face , especially in children who have been abused 
fructose  ||  noun fruit sugar found in honey and some fruit , which together with glucose forms sucrose 
fructosuria  ||  noun the presence of fructose in the urine

fugue  ||  noun a condition in which someone loses his or her memory and leaves home
