inguinal ligament  ||  noun a ligament in the groin , running from the spine to the pubis .  also called pouparts ligament 
inguinal region  ||  noun the part of the body where the lower abdomen joins the top of the thigh .   groin 
inh abbr isoniazid inhalant  ||  noun a medicinal substance which is breathed in 
inhalation  ||  noun 1 .  the act of breathing in .  opposite exhalation 2 .  the action of breathing in a medicinal substance as part of a treatment 
inhale  ||  verb 1 .  to breathe in , or breathe something in  she inhaled some toxic gas fumes and was rushed to hospital .  2 .  to breathe in a medicinal substance as part of a treatment .  opposite exhale 
inhaler  ||  noun a small device for administering medicinal substances into the mouth or nose so that they can be breathed in 
inherent  ||  adjective referring to a thing which is part of the essential character of a person or a permanent characteristic of an organism 
inherit  ||  verb to receive genetically controlled characteristics from a parent  she inherited her fathers red hair .   haemophilia is a condition which is inherited through the mothers genes .  
inheritance  ||  noun 1 .  the process by which genetically controlled characteristics pass from parents to offspring  the inheritance of chronic inflammatory bowel disease 2 .  all of the qualities and characteristics which are passed down from parents  an unfortunate part of our genetic inheritance 
inherited  ||  adjective passed on from a parent through the genes  an inherited disorder of the lungs 
inhibit  ||  verb to prevent an action happening , or stop a functional process  aspirin inhibits the clotting of blood .   to have an inhibiting effect on something to block something , to stop something happening 
inhibition  ||  noun 1 .  the action of blocking or preventing something happening , especially of preventing a muscle or organ from functioning properly 2 .  ( in psychology ) the suppression of a thought which is associated with a sense of guilt 3 .  ( in psychology ) the blocking of a spontaneous action by some mental influence 
inhibitor  ||  noun a substance which inhibits 
inhibitory nerve  ||  noun a nerve which stops a function taking place  the vagus nerve is an inhibitory nerve which slows down the action of the heart . 
inion  ||  noun a part of the occipital bone that can be felt as a slight lump at the back of the skull just above the neck 
inject  ||  verb to put a liquid into someones body under pressure , by using a hollow needle inserted into the tissues o he was injected with morphine .  o she injected herself with a drug .  
injected  ||  adjective 1 .  referring to a liquid or substance introduced into the body 2 .  referring to surface blood vessels which are swollen 
injection  ||  noun 1 .  the act of injecting a liquid into the body o he had a penicillin injection .  2 .  a liquid introduced into the body 
injure  ||  verb to hurt someone or a part of the body o six people were injured in the accident .  
injured  ||  adjective referring to someone who has been hurt • plural noun d the injured people who have been injured o all the injured were taken to the nearest hospital .  
injury  ||  noun damage or a wound caused to a persons body o his injuries required hospital treatment .  o he received severe facial injuries in the accident .  
injury scoring system  ||  noun any system used for deciding how severe an injury is o a standard lung injury scoring system abbr iss 
inlay  ||  noun ( in dentistry ) a type of filling for teeth 
inlet  ||  noun a passage or opening through which a cavity can be entered inn abbr international nonproprietary name 
innards  ||  plural noun the internal organs of the body , especially the intestines 
innate  ||  adjective inherited , which is present in a body from birth 
inner  ||  adjective referring to a part which is inside 
inner ear  ||  noun the part of the ear inside the head , behind the eardrum , containing the semicircular canals , the vestibule and the cochlea 
inner pleura  ||  noun same as visceral pleura 
innervate  ||  verb to cause a muscle , organ or other part of the body to act 
innervation  ||  noun the nerve supply to an organ , including both motor nerves and sensory nerves 
innocent  ||  adjective referring to a growth which is benign , not malignant 
innominate  ||  adjective with no name 
innominate artery  ||  noun the largest branch of the arch of the aorta , which continues as the right common carotid and right subclavian arteries 
innominate bone  ||  noun same as hip bone 
innominate vein  ||  noun same as brachiocephalic vein 
inoculant  ||  noun same as inoculum 
inoculate  ||  verb to introduce vaccine into a persons body in order to make the body create its own antibodies , so making the person immune to the disease o the baby was inoculated against diphtheria .  ( note :  you inoculate someone with or against a disease .  ) 
inoculation  ||  noun the action of inoculating someone o has the baby had a diphtheria inoculation? 
inoculum  ||  noun a substance used for inoculation , e.g.  a vaccine ( note :  the plural is inocula .  ) 
inoperable  ||  adjective referring to a condition which cannot be operated on o the surgeon decided that the cancer was inoperable .  
inorganic  ||  adjective referring to a substance which is not made from animal or vegetable sources 
inorganic acid  ||  noun an acid which comes from minerals , used in dilute form to help indigestion 
inotropic  ||  adjective affecting the way muscles contract , especially those of the heart 
inpatient  ||  noun someone who stays overnight or for some time in a hospital for treatment or observation .  compare outpatient 
inquest  ||  noun an inquiry by a coroner into the cause of a death comment :  an inquest has to take place where death is violent or not expected , where death could be murder or where a prisoner dies and when police are involved .  
insane  ||  adjective mentally unwell ( dated , informal ) 
insanitary  ||  adjective not hygienic o cholera spread rapidly because of the insanitary conditions in the town .  
insect  ||  noun a small animal with six legs and a body in three parts 
insect bite  ||  noun a sting caused by an insect which punctures the skin to suck blood , and in so doing introduces irritants comment :  most insect bites are simply irritating .  others can be more serious , as insects can carry the organisms which produce typhus , sleeping sickness , malaria , filariasis and many other diseases .  
insecticide  ||  noun a substance which kills insects 
insemination  ||  noun the 
introduction of sperm into the vagina 
insensible  ||  adjective 1 .  lacking feeling or consciousness 2 .  not aware of or responding to a stimulus 3 .  too slight to be perceived by the senses 
insert  ||  verb to put something into something  the catheter is inserted into the passage .  
insertion  ||  noun 1 .  the point of attachment of a muscle to a bone 2 .  the point where an organ is attached to its support 3 .  a change in the structure of a chromosome , where a segment of the chromosome is introduced into another member of the complement 
insides  ||  plural noun internal organs , especially the stomach and intestines ( informal )  he says he has a pain in his insides .   you ought to see the doctor if you think there is something wrong with your insides .  
insidious  ||  adjective causing harm without showing any obvious signs 
insidious disease  ||  noun a disease which causes damage before being detected 
insight  ||  noun the ability of a person to realise that he or she is ill or has particular problems or characteristics 
insipidus  ||   diabetes 
insipidus in situ  ||  adverb in place 
insoluble  ||  adjective not able to be dissolved in liquid 
insoluble fibre  ||  noun the fibre in bread and cereals , which is not digested but which swells inside the intestine 
insomnia  ||  noun the inability to sleep  she experiences insomnia .   what does the doctor give you for your insomnia? also called sleeplessness 
insomniac  ||  noun a person who has insomnia 
inspiration  ||  noun the act of taking air into the lungs .  opposite expiration comment :  inspiration takes place when the muscles of the diaphragm contract , allowing the lungs to expand .  
inspiratory  ||  adjective referring to breathing in 
inspire  ||  verb to inhale air or a gas into the lungs 
inspissated  ||  adjective referring to a liquid which is thickened by removing water from it 
inspissation  ||  noun the act of removing water from a solution to make it thicker 
instep  ||  noun an arched top part of the foot 
instil  ||  , instill verb to put a liquid in something drop by drop  instil four drops in each nostril twice a day .  
instillation  ||  noun 1 .  the process of putting a liquid in drop by drop 2 .  a liquid put in drop by drop 
instinct  ||  noun a tendency or ability which the body has from birth and does not need to learn  the body has a natural instinct to protect itself from danger .  
instinctive  ||  adjective automatic or unconscious rather than planned  an instinctive reaction 
institution  ||  noun a place where people are cared for , e.g.  a hospital or clinic , especially a psychiatric hospital or childrens home 
institutionalisation  ||  , institutionalization , institutional neurosis  ||  noun a condition in which someone has become so adapted to life in an institution that it is impossible for him or her to live outside it 
institutionalise  ||  , institutionalize verb to put someone into an institution 
instructions  ||  plural noun spoken or written information which explains how something is used or how to do something  she gave the taxi driver instructions on how to get to the hospital .   the instructions are written on the medicine bottle .   we can’t use this machine because we have lost the book of instructions .  
instrument  ||  noun a piece of equipment or a tool  the doctor had a box of surgical instruments .  
instrumental  ||  adjective  instrumental in helping to do something  she was instrumental in developing the new technique .  
instrumental delivery  ||  noun childbirth where the doctor uses forceps to help the baby out of the mothers uterus 
insufficiency  ||  noun 1 .  the fact of not being strong or large enough to perform usual functions  the patient is suffering from a renal insufficiency .  2 .  the incompetence of an organ 
insufflate  ||  verb to blow gas , vapour or powder into the lungs or another body cavity as a treatment 
insufflation  ||  noun the act of blowing gas , vapour or powder into the lungs or another body cavity as a treatment 
insula  ||  noun part of the cerebral cortex which is covered by the folds of the sulcus 
insulin  ||  noun a hormone produced by the islets of langerhans in the pancreas comment :  insulin controls the way in which the body converts sugar into energy and regulates the level of sugar in the blood .  a lack of insulin caused by diabetes mellitus makes the level of glucose in the blood rise .  insulin injections are regularly used to treat diabetes mellitus , but care has to be taken not to exceed the dose as this will cause hyperinsulinism and hypoglycaemia .  
insulinase  ||  noun an enzyme which breaks down insulin 
insulin dependence  ||  noun the fact of being dependent on insulin injections 
insulin - dependent diabetes  ||  noun same as type i diabetes mellitus 
insulinoma  ||  noun a tumour in the islets of langerhans 
insulin - resistant  ||  adjective referring to a condition in which the muscle and other tissue cells respond inadequately to insulin , as in type ii diabetes 
insulin shock  ||  noun a serious drop in blood sugar , caused by too much insulin accompanied by sweating , dizziness , trembling and eventually coma 
insuloma  ||  noun same as insulinoma 
insult  ||  noun 1 .  a physical injury or trauma 2 .  something that causes a physical injury or trauma 
intact  ||  adjective having all body parts present and undamaged 
intake  ||  noun 1 .  the amount of a substance taken in  a high intake of alcohol  she was advised to reduce her intake of sugar .  2 .  the process of taking in a substance 
intal  ||  a trade name for a preparation of cromolyn sodium 
integrated service  ||  noun a broad care service provided by health and social agencies acting together 
integrative medicine  ||  noun the combination of mainstream therapies and those complementary or alternative therapies for which there is scientific evidence of efficacy and safety 
integument  ||  noun a covering layer , e.g.  the skin 
intellect  ||  noun a persons ability to think , reason and understand 
intelligence  ||  noun the ability to learn and understand quickly 
intelligence quotient  ||  noun the ratio of the mental age , as given by an intelligence test , to the chronological age of the person .  abbr iq 
intense  ||  adjective referring to a very strong pain  she is suffering from intense post herpetic neuralgia .  
intensity  ||  noun the strength of e.g. pain 
intensive care  ||  noun 1 .  the continual supervision and treatment of an extremely ill person in a special section of a hospital  the patient was put in intensive care .   residential care 2 .  same as intensive care unit 
intensive care unit  ||  noun a section of a hospital equipped with lifesaving and life - support equipment in which seriously ill people who need constant medical attention are cared for .  abbr icu 
intention  ||  noun a plan to do something 
intention tremor  ||  noun a trembling of the hands seen when people suffering from particular brain diseases make voluntary movements to try to touch something 
inter -  ||  prefix between 
interaction  ||  noun an effect which two or more substances such as drugs have on each other 
interatrial septum  ||  noun a membrane between the right and left atria in the heart 
intercalated  ||  adjective inserted between other tissues 
intercalated disc  ||  noun closely applied cell membranes at the end of adjacent cells in cardiac muscle , seen as transverse lines 
intercellular  ||  adjective between the cells in tissue 
intercostal  ||  adjective between the ribs  noun same as intercostal muscle 
intercostal muscle  ||  noun one of the muscles between the ribs comment :  the intercostal muscles expand and contract the thorax , so changing the pressure in the thorax and making the person breathe in or out .  there are three layers of intercostal muscle :  external , internal and innermost or intercostalis intimis .  
intercourse  ||  noun same as sexual intercourse 
intercurrent disease  ||  , intercurrent infection  ||  noun a disease or infection which affects someone who has another disease 
interdigital  ||  adjective referring to the space between the fingers or toes 
interdisciplinary  ||  adjective combining two or more different areas of medical or scientific study 
interferon  ||  noun a protein produced by cells , usually in response to a virus , and which then reduces the spread of viruses comment :  although it is now possible to synthesise interferon outside the body , large - scale production is extremely expensive and the substance has not proved as successful at combating viruses as had been hoped , though it is used in multiple sclerosis with some success .  
interior  ||  noun a part which is inside  adjective inside 
interleukin  ||  noun a protein produced by the bodys immune system 
interleukin - 1  ||  noun a protein which causes high temperature .  abbr il - 1 
interleukin - 2  ||  noun a protein which stimulates t - cell production , used in the treatment of cancer .  abbr il - 2 
interlobar  ||  adjective between lobes 
interlobar artery  ||  noun an artery running towards the cortex on each side of a renal pyramid 
interlobular  ||  adjective between lobules 
interlobular artery  ||  noun one of the arteries running to the glomeruli of the kidneys 
intermediate care  ||  noun care following surgery or illness that can be delivered in special units attached to a hospital or in the persons home by a special multidisciplinary team 
intermedius  ||   vastus intermedius 
intermenstrual  ||  adjective between the menstrual periods 
intermittent  ||  adjective occurring at intervals 
intermittent claudication  ||  noun a condition of the arteries causing severe pain in the legs which makes the person limp after having walked a short distance ( note :  the symptoms increase with walking , stop after a short rest and recur when the person walks again .  ) 
intermittent fever  ||  noun fever which rises and falls regularly , as in malaria 
intermittent self - catheterisation  ||  noun a procedure in which someone puts a catheter through the urethra into their own bladder from time to time to empty out the urine .  abbr 
isc 
intern  ||  noun us a medical graduate who is working in a hospital before being licensed to practise medicine .   house officer 
interna  ||   otitis interna 
internal  ||  adjective inside the body or a body part .  opposite external  the drug is for internal use only it should not be used on the outside of the body 
internal auditory meatus  ||  noun a channel which takes the auditory nerve through the temporal bone 
internal bleeding  ||  noun loss of blood inside the body , e.g.  from a wound in the intestine 
internal capsule  ||  noun a bundle of fibres linking the cerebral cortex and other parts of the brain 
internal cardiac massage  ||  noun a method of making the heart start beating again by pressing on the heart itself 
internal carotid  ||  noun an artery in the neck , behind the external carotid , which gives off the ophthalmic artery and ends by dividing into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries 
internal derangement of the knee  ||  noun a condition in which the knee cannot function properly because of a torn meniscus .  abbr idk 
internal ear  ||  noun the part of the ear inside the head , behind the eardrum , containing the semicircular canals , the vestibule and the cochlea 
internal haemorrhage  ||  noun a haemorrhage which takes place inside the body 
internal haemorrhoids  ||  plural noun swollen veins inside the anus 
internal iliac artery  ||  noun an artery which branches from the aorta in the abdomen and leads to the pelvis 
internal injury  ||  noun damage to one of the internal organs 
internal jugular  ||  noun the largest jugular vein in the neck , leading to the brachiocephalic veins 
internally  ||  adverb inside the body  he was bleeding internally .  
internal medicine  ||  noun us the treatment of diseases of the internal organs by specialists 
internal nares  ||  plural noun the two openings shaped like funnels leading from the nasal cavity to the pharynx .  also called posterior nares 
internal oblique  ||  noun the middle layer of muscle covering the abdomen , beneath the external oblique 
internal organ  ||  noun an organ situated inside the body 
internal respiration  ||  noun the part of respiration concerned with the passage of oxygen from the blood to the tissues , and thepassage of carbon dioxide from the tissues to the blood 
international committee of the red cross  ||  noun an international organisation which provides mainly emergency medical help , but also relief to victims of earthquakes , floods and other disasters , or to prisoners of war .  abbr icrc 
international council of nurses  ||  noun an organisation founded in 1899 which now represents nurses in more than 120 countries .  its aims are to bring nurses together , to advance nursing worldwide and to influence health policies .  abbr icn 
international nonproprietary name  ||  noun each of 8 ,000 names selected by the world health organization that are the legally required generic names for pharmaceutical product labelling for most countries in the world , including all eu countries .  abbr inn 
international unit  ||  noun an internationally agreed standard used in pharmacy as a measure of a substance such as a drug or hormone .  abbr iu 
interneurone  ||  noun a neurone with short processes which is a link between two other neurones in sensory or motor pathways 
internist  ||  noun a specialist who treats diseases of the internal organs by nonsurgical means 
internodal  ||  adjective between two nodes 
internuncial neurone  ||  noun a neurone which links two other nerve cells 
internus  ||  noun medial rectus muscle in the orbit of the eye 
interoceptor  ||  noun a nerve cell which reacts to a change taking place inside the body 
interosseous  ||  adjective between bones 
interparietal  ||  adjective between parietal parts , especially between the parietal bones  noun same as interparietal bone 
interparietal bone  ||  noun a triangular bone in the back of the skull , rarely present in humans 
interpeduncular cistern  ||  noun subarachnoid space between the two cerebral hemispheres beneath the midbrain and the hypothalamus 
interphalangeal joint  ||  noun a joint between the phalanges .  also called ip joint 
interphase  ||  noun a stage of a cell between divisions 
interpubic joint  ||  noun a piece of cartilage which joins the two sections of the pubic bone .  also called pubic symphysis 
interruptus  ||   coitus interruptus 
intersex  ||  noun an organism that has both male and female characteristics 
intersexuality  ||  noun a condition in which a baby has both male and female characteristics , as in klinefelters syndrome and turners syndrome 
interstice  ||  noun a small space between body parts or within a tissue 
interstitial  ||  adjective referring to tissue located in the spaces between parts of something , especially between the active tissues in an organ 
interstitial cell  ||  noun a testosterone - producing cell between the tubules in the testes .  also called leydig cell 
interstitial cell stimulating hormone  ||  noun a hormone produced by the pituitary gland which stimulates the formation of corpus luteum in females and testosterone in males .  abbr icsh .  also called luteinising hormone 
interstitial cystitis  ||  noun a persistent nonbacterial condition in which someone has bladder pain and wants to pass urine frequently . it is often associated with hunners ulcer .  
intertrigo  ||  noun an irritation which occurs when two skin surfaces rub against each other , as in the armpit or between the buttocks 
intertubercular plane  ||  noun same as transtubercular plane 
intervention  ||  noun a treatment 
interventional radiology  ||  noun the area of medicine which uses x - rays , ultrasound and computer - assisted tomography to guide small instruments into the body for procedures such as biopsies , draining fluids or widening narrow vessels 
interventricular  ||  adjective between ventricles in the heart or brain 
interventricular foramen  ||  noun an opening in the brain between the lateral ventricle and the third ventricle , through which the cerebrospinal fluid passes 
interventricular septum  ||  noun a membrane between the right and left ventricles in the heart 
intervertebral  ||  adjective between vertebrae 
intervertebral disc  ||  noun a round plate of cartilage which separates two vertebrae in the spinal column .  see illustration at cartilaginous joint in supplement .  also called vertebral disc 
intervertebral foramen  ||  noun a space between two vertebrae 
intestinal  ||  adjective referring to the intestine 
intestinal anastomosis  ||  noun a surgical operation to join one part of the intestine to another , after a section has been removed 
intestinal flora  ||  plural noun beneficial bacteria which are always present in the intestine 
intestinal glands  ||  plural noun tubular glands found in the mucous membrane of the small and large intestine , especially those between the bases of the villi in the small intestine .  also called lieberkühns glands , crypts of lieberkühn 
intestinal infection  ||  noun an infection in the intestines 
intestinal juice  ||  noun alkaline liquid secreted by the small intestine which helps to digest food 
intestinal obstruction  ||  noun a blocking of the intestine 
intestinal villi  ||  plural noun projections on the walls of the intestine which help in the digestion of food 
intestinal wall  ||  noun the layers of tissue which form the intestine 
intestine  ||  noun the part of the digestive system between the stomach and the anus that digests and absorbs food .   large intestine , small intestine ( note :  for other terms referring to the intestines , see words beginning with entero -  .  ) 
intima  ||   tunica intima 
intolerance  ||  noun the fact of being unable to endure something such as pain or to take a medicine without an adverse reaction  he developed an intolerance to penicillin .  
intoxicant  ||  noun a substance which induces a state of intoxication or poisoning , e.g.  an alcoholic drink 
intoxicate  ||  verb to make someone incapable of controlling his or her actions , because of the influence of alcohol on the nervous system  he drank six glasses of whisky and became completely intoxicated .  
intoxication  ||  noun a condition which results from the absorption and diffusion in the body of a substance such as alcohol  she was driving in a state of intoxication .  
intra -  ||  prefix inside 
intra - abdominal  ||  adjective inside the abdomen 
intra - articular  ||  adjective inside a joint 
intracellular  ||  adjective inside a cell 
intracerebral haematoma  ||  noun a blood clot inside a cerebral hemisphere 
intracranial  ||  adjective inside the skull 
intracranial pressure  ||  noun the pressure of the subarachnoidal fluid , which fills the space between the skull and the brain .  abbr icp 
intractable  ||  adjective not able to be controlled  an operation to relieve intractable pain 
intracutaneous  ||  adjective inside layers of skin tissue 
intracutaneous injection  ||  noun an injection of a liquid between the layers of skin , as for a test for an allergy 
intradermal  ||  adjective within or introduced between the layers of the skin 
intradermal test  ||  noun a test requiring an injection into the thickness of the skin , e.g.  a mantoux test or an allergy test 
intradermic  ||  adjective same as intradermal 
intradural  ||  adjective inside the dura mater 
intramedullary  ||  adjective inside the bone marrow or spinal cord 
intramural  ||  adjective inside the wall of an organ 
intramuscular  ||  adjective inside a muscle 
intramuscular injection  ||  noun an injection of liquid into a muscle , e.g.  for a slow release of a drug 
intranasal  ||  adjective inside or into the nose 
intraocular  ||  adjective inside the eye 
intraocular lens  ||  noun an artificial lens implanted inside the eye .  abbr iol 
intraocular pressure  ||  noun the pressure inside the eyeball ( note :  if the pressure is too high , it causes glaucoma .  ) intraoperative ultrasound noun high - resolution imaging used in surgery .  abbr ious 
intraorbital  ||  adjective within the orbit of the eye 
intraosseous  ||  adjective within a bone 
intrathecal  ||  adjective inside a sheath , especially inside the intradural or sub - arachnoid space 
intratracheal  ||  adjective within the trachea .  also called endotracheal 
intratubercular plane  ||  noun a plane at right angles to the sagittal plane , passing through the tubercles of the iliac crests 
intrauterine  ||  adjective inside the uterus 
intrauterine contraceptive device  ||  , intrauterine device  ||  noun a plastic coil placed inside the uterus to prevent pregnancy .  abbr iucd , iud 
intravascular  ||  adjective inside the blood vessels 
intravenous  ||  adjective into a vein .  abbr iv 
intravenous drip  ||  noun a thin tube that is inserted into a vein and is used to very gradually give a person fluids , either for rehydration , feeding or medication purposes 
intravenous feeding  ||  noun the procedure of giving someone liquid food by means of a tube inserted into a vein 
intravenous injection  ||  noun an injection of liquid into a vein , e.g.  for the fast release of a drug 
intravenously  ||  adverb into a vein  a fluid given intravenously 
intravenous pyelogram  ||  , intravenous urogram  ||  noun a series of x - ray photographs of the kidneys using pyelography .  abbr ivp 
intravenous pyelography  ||  , intravenous urography  ||  noun an x - ray examination of the urinary tract after opaque liquid has been injected intravenously into the body and taken by the blood into the kidneys 
intraventricular  ||  adjective inside or placed into a ventricle in the heart or the brain 
intra vitam  ||  adverb during life 
intrinsic  ||  adjective belonging to the essential nature of an organism , or entirely within an organ or part 
intrinsic factor  ||  noun a protein produced in the gastric glands which reacts with the extrinsic factor , and which , if lacking , causes pernicious anaemia 
intrinsic ligament  ||  noun a ligament which forms part of the capsule surrounding a joint 
intrinsic muscle  ||  noun a muscle lying completely inside the part or segment , especially of a limb , which it moves 
intro -  ||  prefix inward 
introduce  ||  verb 1 .  to put something into something  he used a syringe to introduce a medicinal substance into the body .   the nurse introduced the catheter into the vein .  2 .  to present two people to one another when they have never met before  can i introduce my new assistant? 3 .  to start a new way of doing something  the hospital has introduced a new screening process for cervical cancer .  
introduction  ||  noun 1 .  the act of putting something inside something  the introduction of semen into the womans uterus  the introduction of an endotracheal tube into the patients mouth 2 .  the act of starting a new process 
introitus  ||  noun an opening into any hollow organ or canal 
introjection  ||  noun a persons unconscious adoption of the attitudes or values of another person whom he or she wants to impress 
introspection  ||  noun a detailed and sometimes obsessive mental self - examination of feelings , thoughts and motives 
introversion  ||  noun a condition in which a person is excessively interested in himself or herself and his or her own mental state .  compare extroversion 
introvert  ||  noun a person who thinks only about himself or herself and his or her own mental state .  compare extrovert 
introverted  ||  adjective referring to someone who thinks only about himself or herself 
intubate  ||  verb to insert a tube into any organ or part of the body .  also called catheterise 
intubation  ||  noun the therapeutic insertion of a tube into the larynx through the glottis to allow the passage of air .  also called catheterisation 
intumescence  ||  noun the swelling of an organ 
intussusception  ||  noun a condition in which part of the gastrointestinal tract becomes folded down inside the part beneath it , causing an obstruction and strangulation of the folded part 
inunction  ||  noun 1 .  the act of rubbing an ointment into the skin so that the medicine in it is absorbed 2 .  an ointment which is rubbed into the skin 
in utero  ||  adverb , adjective in , or while still inside , a womans womb 
invade  ||  verb to enter and spread gradually throughout a part of the body , e.g.  the entry of a microorganism that causes disease 
invagination  ||  noun 1 .  same as intussusception 2 .  the surgical treatment of hernia , in which a sheath of tissue is made to cover the opening 
invalid  ||  ( dated ) noun someone who has had an illness and has not fully recovered from it or who has been permanently disabled  adjective weak or disabled 
invalidity  ||  noun the condition of being disabled 
invasion  ||  noun the entry of bacteria into a body , or the first attack of a disease 
invasive  ||  adjective 1 .  referring to cancer which tends to spread throughout the body 2 .  referring to an inspection or treatment which involves entering the body by making an incision .   non - invasive 
inverse care law  ||  noun the idea that the people who most need care and services are least likely or able to access them 
inversion  ||  noun the fact of being turned towards the inside  inversion of the foot see illustration at anatomical terms in supplement  inversion of the uterus a condition in which the top part of the uterus touches the cervix , as if it were inside out , which may happen after childbirth 
invertase  ||  noun an enzyme in the intestine which splits sucrose 
investigation  ||  noun an examination to find out the cause of something which has happened  the health authority ordered an investigation into how the drugs were stolen .  
investigative surgery  ||  noun surgery to investigate the cause of a condition 
in vitro  ||  adjective , adverb a latin phrase meaning ‘in a glass’ , i . e .  in a test tube or similar container used in a laboratory  in vitro activity , in vitro experiment experiment which takes place in the laboratory 
in vitro fertilisation  ||  noun the fertilisation of an ovum in the laboratory .   test - tube baby .  abbr ivf in vivo adjective , adverb a latin phrase meaning ‘in living tissue’ , i . e .  referring to an experiment which takes place on the living body 
in vivo experiment  ||  noun an experiment on a living body , e.g. that of an animal 
involucrum  ||  noun a covering of new bone which forms over diseased bone 
involuntary  ||  adjective done automatically , without any conscious thought or decision - making being involved  patients are advised not to eat or drink , to reduce the risk of involuntary vomiting while on the operating table .  
involuntary action  ||  noun an action which someone does without thinking or making a conscious decision 
involuntary muscle  ||  noun a muscle supplied by the autonomic nervous system , and therefore not under voluntary control , e.g.  the muscle which activates a vital organ such as the heart 
involution  ||  noun 1 .  the return of an organ to its usual size , e.g.  the shrinking of the uterus after childbirth 2 .  a period of decline of organs which sets in after middle age 
involutional  ||  adjective referring to involution 
involutional melancholia  ||  noun a depression which occurs in people , mainly women , after middle age , probably caused by a change of endocrine secretions 
iodine  ||  noun a chemical element which is essential to the body , especially to the functioning of the thyroid gland ( note :  lack of iodine in the diet can cause goitre .  the chemical symbol is i .  ) 
iol abbr intraocular lens 
ion  ||  noun an atom that has an electric charge ( note :  ions with a positive charge are called cations and those with a negative charge are called anions .  ) comment :  it is believed that living organisms , including human beings , react to the presence of ionised particles in the atmosphere .  hot dry winds contain a higher proportion of positive ions than usual and these winds cause headaches and other illnesses .  if negative ionised air is introduced into an air - conditioning system , the incidence of headaches and nausea among people working in the building may be reduced .  
ionise  ||  , ionize verb to give an atom an electric charge 
ioniser  ||  , ionizer noun a machine that increases the amount of negative ions in the atmosphere of a room , so counteracting the effect of positive ions 
ionotherapy  ||  noun treatment by ions introduced into the body via an electric current 
iontophoresis  ||  noun the movement of ions through a biological material when an electric current passes through it 
ious abbr intraoperative ultrasound 
ipav abbr intermittent positive airway ventilation .   positive pressure ventilation 
ipecacuanha  ||  noun a drug made from the root of an american plant , used as a treatment for coughs , and also as an emetic ( note :  the us term is ipecac .  ) 
ip joint  ||  noun same as interphalangeal joint 
ippv abbr intermittent positive pressure ventilation .   positive pressure ventilation 
ipratropium  ||  , ipratropium bromide  ||  noun a drug which helps to relax muscles in the airways , used in the treatment of conditions such as asthma , bronchitis and emphysema 
ipsilateral  ||  adjective located on or affecting the same side of the body .  also called homolateral .  opposite contralateral 
iq abbr intelligence quotient irds abbr infant respiratory distress syndrome 
irid -  ||  prefix referring to the iris 
iridectomy  ||  noun the surgical removal of part of the iris 
iridencleisis  ||  noun an operation to treat glaucoma , where part of the iris is used as a drainage channel through a hole in the conjunctiva 
iridocyclitis  ||  noun inflammation of the iris and the tissues which surround it 
iridodialysis  ||  noun the separation of the iris from its insertion 
iridoplegia  ||  noun paralysis of the iris 
iridoptosis  ||  noun the pushing forward of the iris through a wound in the cornea 
iridotomy  ||  noun a surgical incision into the iris 
iris  ||  noun a coloured ring in the eye , with the pupil at its centre .  see illustration at eye in supplement comment :  the iris acts like the aperture in a camera shutter , opening and closing to allow more or less light through the pupil into the eye .  
iritis  ||  noun inflammation of the iris 
iron  ||  noun 1 .  a chemical element essential to the body , present in foods such as liver and eggs 2 .  a common grey metal ( note :  the chemical symbol is fe .  ) comment :  iron is an essential part of the red pigment in red blood cells .  lack of iron in haemoglobin results in iron - deficiency anaemia .  storage of too much iron in the body results in haemochromatosis .  
iron - deficiency anaemia  ||  noun anaemia caused by a lack of iron in red blood cells 
iron lung  ||  noun same as drinker respirator 
irradiation  ||  noun 1 .  the process of spreading from a centre , as e.g.  , nerve impulses do 2 .  the use of radiation to treat people or to kill bacteria in food 
irreducible hernia  ||  noun a hernia where the organ cannot be returned to its usual position 
irregular  ||  adjective not regular or normal  the patients breathing was irregular .   the nurse noted that the patient had developed an irregular pulse .   he has irregular bowel movements .  
irrigate  ||  verb to wash out a cavity in the body 
irrigation  ||  noun the washing out of a cavity in the body 
irritability  ||  noun the state of being irritable 
irritable  ||  adjective 1 .  easily able to become inflamed and painful 2 .  feeling annoyed and impatient 
irritable bowel syndrome  ||  noun  mucous colitis .  abbr ibs 
irritable colon  ||  noun  mucous colitis 
irritable hip  ||  noun a condition of pain in the hip which is caused by swelling of the synovium .  treatment involves bed rest , traction and anti - inflammatory drugs .  
irritant  ||  noun a substance which can irritate 
irritant dermatitis  ||  noun same as contact dermatitis 
irritate  ||  verb to cause a painful reaction in part of the body , especially to make it inflamed  some types of wool can irritate the skin .  
irritation  ||  noun a feeling of being irritated  an irritation caused by the ointment 
isc abbr intermittent self - catheterisation 
isch -  ||  prefix too little 
ischaemia  ||  noun a deficient blood supply to a part of the body 
ischaemic  ||  adjective lacking in blood ‘…the term stroke does not refer to a single pathological entity .  stroke may be haemorrhagic or is
chaemic :  the latter is usually caused by thrombosis or embolism’ [british journal of hospital medicine] 
ischaemic heart disease  ||  noun a disease of the heart caused by a failure in the blood supply , as in coronary thrombosis .  abbr ihd 
ischi -  ||  prefix same as ischio - ( used before vowels ) 
ischia  ||  plural of ischium 
ischial  ||  adjective referring to the ischium or hip joint 
ischial tuberosity  ||  noun a lump of bone forming the ring of the ischium 
ischio -  ||  prefix referring to the ischium 
ischiocavernosus muscle  ||  noun a muscle along one side of the perineum 
ischiorectal  ||  adjective referring to both the ischium and the rectum 
ischiorectal abscess  ||  noun an abscess which forms in fat cells between the anus and the ischium 
ischiorectal fossa  ||  noun a space on either side of the lower end of the rectum and anal canal 
ischium  ||  noun the lower part of the hip bone in the pelvis .  see illustration at pelvis in supplement ( note :  the plural is ischia .  ) 
ishihara colour charts  ||  plural noun charts used in a test for col - our vision in which numbers or letters are shown in dots of primary colours with dots of other colours around them .  people with normal colour vision can see them , but people who are colour - blind cannot .  
ishihara test  ||  noun a test using ishihara colour charts 
islets of langerhans  ||  , islands of langerhans  ||  , islet cells  ||  plural noun groups of cells in the pancreas which secrete the hormones glucagon , insulin and gastrin [described 1869 .  after paul langerhans ( 1847–88 ) , professor of pathological anatomy at freiburg , germany . ] 
iso -  ||  prefix equal 
isoantibody  ||  noun an antibody which forms in one person as a reaction to antigens from another person ( note :  the plural is isoantibodies .  ) 
isograft  ||  noun a graft of tissue from an identical twin .  also called syngraft 
isoimmunisation  ||  ,isoimmunization noun immunisation of a person with antigens derived from another person 
isolate  ||  verb 1 .  to keep one person apart from others because he or she has a dangerous infectious disease 2 .  to identify a single virus , bacterium or other pathogen among many  scientists have been able to isolate the virus which causes legionnaires’ disease .   candida is easily isolated from the mouths of healthy adults .  
isolation  ||  noun the separation of a person , especially one with an infectious disease , from others 
isolation ward  ||  noun a special ward where people who have dangerous infectious diseases can be kept isolated from others 
isolator  ||  noun 1 .  a large clear plastic bag in which a person can be nursed , or operated on , in a sterile environment 2 .  a room or piece of equipment which keeps people or substances separated from others which may contaminate them  an isolator stretcher  an isolator cabinet 
isoleucine  ||  noun an essential amino acid 
isometric  ||  adjective 1 .  involving equal measurement  an isometric view of the system 2 .  referring to muscle contraction in which tension occurs with very little shortening of muscle fibres 3 .  referring to exercises in which the muscles are put under tension but not contracted 
isometrics  ||  plural noun exercises to strengthen the muscles , in which the muscles contract but do not shorten 
isoniazid  ||  noun a colourless crystalline compound that is used in the treatment of tuberculosis .  abbr inh 
isoprenaline  ||  , isoproterenol noun a drug that relieves asthma by widening the bronchial tubes in the lungs 
isosorbide dinitrate  ||  noun a compound which causes widening or relaxation of the blood vessels , used in the treatment of angina pectoris 
isotonic  ||  adjective referring to a solution , e.g.  a saline drip , which has the same osmotic pressure as blood serum and which can therefore be passed directly into the body .  compare hypertonic , hypotonic 
isotonicity  ||  noun the equal osmotic pressure of two or more solutions 
isotonic solution  ||  noun a solution which has the same osmotic pressure as blood serum , or as another liquid it is compared with 
isotope  ||  noun a form of a chemical element which has the same chemical properties as other forms but a different atomic mass 
isotretinoin  ||  noun a drug used in the treatment of severe acne and several other skin diseases 
ispaghula  ||  , ispaghula husk  ||  noun a natural dietary fibre used to treat constipation , diverticulitis and irritable bowel syndrome 
iss abbr injury scoring system 
isthmus  ||  noun 1 .  a short narrow canal or cavity 2 .  a narrow band of tissue joining two larger masses of similar tissue , e.g.  the section in the centre of the thyroid gland , which joins the two lobes ( note :  the plural is isthmi or isthmuses .  ) 
itch  ||  noun 1 .  an irritated place on the skin which makes a person want to scratch 2 .  the itch same as scabies ( informal )  verb to produce an irritating sensation , making someone want to scratch 
itching  ||  noun same as pruritus 
itchy  ||  adjective making a person want to scratch  the main symptom of the disease is an itchy red rash .  
 - itis  ||  suffix inflammation itu abbr intensive therapy unit iu abbr international unit iucd abbr intrauterine contraceptive device iud abbr 1 .  intrauterine death 2 .  intrauterine device ius abbr intrauterine system iv abbr intravenous ivf abbr in vitro fertilisation ivp abbr intravenous pyelogram ivu abbr intravenous urography 

j  ||  abbr joule 
jab  ||  noun an injection or inoculation ( informal )  a tetanus jab 
jacksonian epilepsy  ||  noun a form of epilepsy in which the jerking movements start in one part of the body before spreading to others [described 1863 .  after john hughlings jackson ( 1835– 1911 ) , british neurologist . ] 
jacquemiers sign  ||  noun a sign of early pregnancy in which the vaginal mucosa becomes slightly blue due to an increased amount of blood in the arteries [after jean marie jacquemier ( 1806–79 ) , french obstetrician] 
jactitation  ||  noun the action of constantly moving the body around in a restless way , especially because of mental illness 
jag  ||  noun in scotland , an injection or inoculation ( informal ) 
jargon  ||  noun 1 .  the words used by people who have a particular area of knowledge , which are usually only understood by those people  medical jargon 2 .  a stream of words that makes no sense , produced by someone with aphasia or a severe mental disorder 
jaundice  ||  noun a condition in which there is an excess of bile pigment in the blood , and in which the pigment is deposited in the skin and the whites of the eyes , which have a yellow colour .  also called icterus comment :  jaundice can have many causes , usually relating to the liver :  the most common are blockage of the bile ducts by gallstones or by disease of the liver and weils disease .  
jaw  ||  noun the bones in the face which hold the teeth and form the mouth  he fell down and broke his jaw .   the punch on his mouth broke his jaw .  
comment :  the jaw has two parts , the upper ( the maxillae ) being fixed parts of the skull , and the lower ( the mandible ) being attached to the skull with a hinge so that it can move up and down .  
jawbone  ||  noun one of the bones which form the jaw , especially the lower jaw or mandible 
jejun -  ||  prefix same as jejuno - ( used before vowels ) 
jejunal  ||  adjective referring to the jejunum 
jejunal ulcer  ||  noun an ulcer in the jejunum 
jejunectomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to remove all or part of the jejunum ( note :  the plural is jejunectomies .  ) 
jejuno -  ||  prefix referring to the jejunum 
jejunoileostomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to make an artificial link between the jejunum and the ileum ( note :  the plural is jejunoileostomies .  ) 
jejunostomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to make an artificial passage to the jejunum through the wall of the abdomen ( note :  the plural is jejunostomies .  ) 
jejunotomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to cut into the jejunum ( note :  the plural is jejunotomies .  ) 
jejunum  ||  noun the part of the small intestine between the duodenum and the ileum , about 2 metres long .  see illustration at digestive system in supplement 
jerk  ||  noun a sudden movement of part of the body which indicates that the local reflex arc is intact  verb to make sudden movements , or cause something to make sudden movements  in some forms of epilepsy the limbs jerk .  
jet lag  ||  noun a condition suffered by people who travel long distances in planes , caused by rapid changes in time zones which affect sleep patterns and meal times and thus interfere with the bodys metabolism  we had jet lag when we flew from australia .  
jet - lagged  ||  adjective experiencing jet lag  jet - lagged travellers  we were jet - lagged for a week .  
joint  ||  noun a structure at a point where two or more bones join , especially one which allows movement of the bones  the elbow is a joint in the arm .   arthritis is accompanied by stiffness in the joints .   charcots 
joint ( note :  for other terms referring to joints , see words beginning with arthr -  , arthro -  .  ) 
joint - breaker fever  ||  noun same as o’nyong - nyong fever 
joint capsule  ||  noun white fibrous tissue which surrounds and holds a joint together .  see illustration at synovial joint in supplement 
joint investment plan  ||  noun a plan that health and social services draw up together for specific areas of care 
joint mouse  ||  plural noun a loose piece of bone or cartilage in the knee joint , making the joint lock 
joule  ||  noun the si unit of measurement of work or energy .  4 . 184 joules equals one calorie .  symbol j 
jugular  ||  adjective referring to the throat or neck  noun same as jugular vein comment :  there are three jugular veins on each side :  the internal jugular is large and leads to the brachiocephalic vein , the external jugular is smaller and leads to the subclavian vein and the anterior jugular is the smallest .  
jugular nerve  ||  noun one of the nerves in the neck 
jugular trunk  ||  noun a terminal lymph vessel in the neck , draining into the subclavian vein 
jugular vein  ||  noun one of the veins which pass down either side of the neck .  also called 
jugular juice  ||  noun 1 .  liquid from a fruit or vegetable  a glass of orange juice or tomato juice 2 .  a natural fluid of the body .   gastric juice 
jumpers knee  ||  noun a painful condition suffered by athletes and dancers in which inflammation develops in the knee joint 
junction  ||  noun a joining point 
junior doctor  ||  noun a doctor who is completing his or her training in hospital 
junk food  ||  noun food of little nutritional value , e.g.  high - fat processed snacks , eaten between or instead of meals 
juvenile  ||  adjective relating to or affecting children or adolescents 
juxta -  ||  prefix beside or near 
juxta - articular  ||  adjective occurring near a joint 

k symbol kilo - 
kahn test  ||  noun a test of blood serum to diagnose syphilis [described 1922 .  after reuben leon kahn , lithuanian - born serologist who worked in the usa . ] 
kala - azar  ||  noun an often fatal form of leishmaniasis caused by the infection of the intestines and internal organs by a parasite , leishmania , spread by flies .  symptoms are fever , anaemia , general wasting of the body and swelling of the spleen and liver .  
kalium  ||  noun same as potassium 
kaolin  ||  noun a fine soft clay used in the making of medical preparations , especially for the treatment of diarrhoea 
kaposis sarcoma  ||  noun a cancer which takes the form of many haemorrhagic nodes affecting the skin , especially on the extremities [described 1872 .  after moritz kohn karposi ( 1837–1902 ) , professor of dermatology at vienna , austria . ] comment :  formerly a relatively rare disease , found mainly in tropical countries , kaposis sarcoma is now more common as it is one of the diseases associated with aids .  
kartageners syndrome  ||  noun a hereditary condition in which all the organs in the chest and abdomen are positioned on the opposite side from the usual one , i . e .  the heart and stomach are on the right 
karyo -  ||  prefix relating to a cell nucleus 
karyotype  ||  noun the chromosome complement of a cell , shown as a diagram or as a set of letters and numbers 
kawasaki disease  ||  noun a retrovirus infection that often occurs in small children and causes a high temperature , rash , reddened eyes , peeling skin and swollen lymph nodes 
kayser - fleischer ring  ||  noun a brown ring on the outer edge of the cornea , which is a diagnostic sign of hepatolenticular degeneration [described 1902 by kayser , 1903 by fleischer .  bernard kayser ( 1869– 1954 ) , german ophthalmologist ; bruno richard fleischer ( 1848–1904 ) , german physician . ] 
kcal abbr kilocalorie 
kegel exercises  ||  plural noun exercises which strengthen the muscles of the pelvic floor in women and help to prevent any accidental leakage of urine when they cough , sneeze or lift things 
kellers operation  ||  noun a surgical operation on the big toe to remove a bunion or to correct an ankylosed joint [described 1904 .  after william lordan keller ( 1874–1959 ) , us surgeon . ] 
keloid  ||  noun an excessive amount of scar tissue at the site of a skin injury 
kerat -  ||  prefix same as kerato - ( used before vowels ) 
keratalgia  ||  noun pain felt in the cornea 
keratectasia  ||  noun a condition in which the cornea bulges 
keratectomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to remove the whole or part of the cornea ( note :  the plural is keratectomies .  ) 
keratic  ||  adjective 1 .  relating to horny tissue or to keratin 2 .  relating to the cornea 
keratin  ||  noun a protein found in horny tissue such as fingernails , hair or the outer surface of the skin 
keratinisation  ||  , keratinization noun the appearance of horny characteristics in tissue .  also called cornification 
keratinise  ||  , keratinize verb to convert something into keratin or into horny tissue ( note :  keratinising – keratinised ) 
keratinocyte  ||  noun a cell which produces keratin 
keratitis  ||  noun inflammation of the cornea 
kerato -  ||  prefix referring to horn , horny tissue or the cornea 
keratoacanthoma  ||  noun a type of benign skin tumour which disappears after a few months ( note :  the plural is keratoacanthomas or keratoacanthomata .  ) 
keratoconjunctivitis  ||  noun inflammation of the cornea with conjunctivitis 
keratoconus  ||  noun a cone - shaped lump on the cornea 
keratoglobus  ||  noun swelling of the eyeball 
keratoma  ||  noun a hard thickened growth due to hypertrophy of the horny zone of the skin ( note :  the plural is keratomas or keratomata .  ) 
keratomalacia  ||  noun 1 .  a softening of the cornea frequently caused by vitamin a deficiency 2 .  softening of the horny layer of the skin 
keratome  ||  noun a surgical knife used for operations on the cornea 
keratometer  ||  noun an instrument for measuring the curvature of the cornea 
keratometry  ||  noun the process of measuring the curvature of the cornea 
keratopathy  ||  noun any noninflammatory disorder of the cornea ( note :  the plural is keratopathies .  ) 
keratoplasty  ||  noun a surgical operation to graft corneal tissue from a donor in place of diseased tissue ( note :  the plural is keratoplasties .  ) 
keratoprosthesis  ||  noun 1 .  a surgical operation to replace the central area of a cornea with clear plastic , when it has become opaque 2 .  a piece of clear plastic put into the cornea ( note :  the plural is keratoprostheses .  ) 
keratoscope  ||  noun an instrument for examining the cornea to see if it has an unusual curvature .  also called placidos disc 
keratosis  ||  noun a lesion of the skin ( note :  the plural is keratoses .  ) 
keratotomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to make a cut in the cornea , the first step in many intraocular operations ( note :  the plural is keratotomies .  ) 
kerion  ||  noun a painful soft mass , usually on the scalp , caused by ringworm 
kernicterus  ||  noun yellow pigmentation of the basal ganglia and other nerve cells in the spinal cord and brain , found in children with icterus 
kernigs sign  ||  noun a symptom of meningitis in which the knee cannot be straightened if the person is lying down with the thigh brought up against the abdomen [described 1882 .  after vladimir mikhailovich kernig ( 1840–1917 ) , russian neurologist . ] 
ketamine  ||  noun a white crystalline powder that is a general anaesthetic , used in human and veterinary medicine 
ketoacidosis  ||  noun an accumulation of ketone bodies in tissue in diabetes , causing acidosis 
ketoconazole  ||  noun a drug which is effective against a wide range of fungal infections such as cryptococcosis and thrush 
ketogenesis  ||  noun the production of ketone bodies 
ketogenic  ||  adjective forming ketone bodies 
ketogenic diet  ||  noun a diet with a high fat content , producing ketosis 
ketonaemia  ||  noun a morbid state in which ketone bodies exist in the blood 
ketone  ||  noun a chemical compound produced when glucose is unavailable for use as energy , as in untreated diabetes , and fats are used instead , leading to ketosis 
ketone bodies  ||  plural noun ketone compounds formed from fatty acids 
ketone group  ||  noun a chemical group characteristic of ketones , with carbon atoms doubly bonded to an oxygen atom and to the carbon atoms of two other organic groups 
ketonuria  ||  noun a state in which ketone bodies are excreted in the urine 
ketoprofen  ||  noun an anti - inflammatory drug used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis 
ketosis  ||  noun a state in which ketone bodies such as acetone and acetic acid accumulate in the tissues , a late complication of type i diabetes mellitus 
ketosteroid  ||  noun a steroid such as cortisone which contains a ketone group 
keyhole surgery  ||  noun surgery carried out by inserting tiny surgical instruments through an endoscope ( informal ) also called laparoscopic surgery 
kg abbr kilogram kidney  ||  noun either of two organs situated in the lower part of the back on either side of the spine behind the abdomen , whose function is to maintain the usual concentrations of the main constituents of blood , passing the waste matter into the urine .  see illustration at kidney in supplement comment :  a kidney is formed of an outer cortex and an inner medulla .  the nephrons which run from the cortex into the medulla filter the blood and form urine .  the urine is passed through the ureters into the bladder .  sudden sharp pain in back of the abdomen , going downwards , is an indication of a kidney stone passing into the ureter .  
kidney dialysis  ||  noun the process of removing waste matter from blood by passing it through a kidney machine .  also called haemodialysis 
kidney donor  ||  noun a person who gives one of his or her kidneys as a transplant 
kidney failure  ||  noun a situation in which the kidneys do not function properly 
kidney machine  ||  noun an apparatus through which blood is passed to be cleaned by dialysis if the persons kidneys have failed 
kidney stone  ||  noun a hard mass of calcium like a little piece of stone which forms in the kidney 
kidney transplant  ||  noun a surgical operation to give someone with a diseased or damaged kidney a kidney from another person 
kill  ||  verb to make someone or something die  she was killed in a car crash .   heart attacks kill more people every year .   antibodies are created to kill bacteria .  
killer  ||  noun a person or disease which kills  in the winter , bronchitis is the killer of hundreds of senior citizens .   virulent typhoid fever can be a killer disease .   painkiller 
killer cell  ||  , killer t cell noun a type of immune cell that recognises and destroys cells that have specific antigens on their surface , e.g.  virus - infected or cancerous cells 
killians operation  ||  noun a surgical operation to clear the frontal sinus by curetting in which the incision is made in the eyebrow [after gustav killian ( 1860– 1921 ) , german laryngologist] 
kilo -  ||  prefix one thousand ( 103 ) .  symbol k 
kilogram  ||  noun an si unit of measurement of weight equal to 1000 grams  she weighs 62 kilos ( 62 kg ) .  symbol kg 
kilojoule  ||  noun an si unit of measurement of energy or heat equal to 1000 joules .  symbol kj 
kilopascal  ||  noun an si unit of measurement of pressure equal to 1000 pascals .  symbol kpa 
kimmelstiel - wilson disease  ||  , kimmelstiel - wilson syndrome  ||  noun a form of nephrosclerosis found in people with diabetes [described 1936 .  after paul kimmelstiel ( 1900–70 ) , us pathologist ; clifford wilson ( 1906–98 ) , professor of medicine , london university , uk . ] 
kin  ||  noun relatives or close members of the family 
kin -  ||  prefix same as kine - ( used before vowels ) 
kinaesthesia  ||  noun the fact of being aware of the movement and position of parts of the body ( note :  the us spelling is kinesthesia .  ) comment :  kinaesthesia is the result of information from muscles and ligaments which is passed to the brain and which allows the brain to recognise movements , touch and weight .  
kinanaesthesia  ||  noun the fact of not being able to sense the movement and position of parts of the body ( note :  the us spelling is kinanesthesia .  ) 
kinase  ||  noun an enzyme belonging to a large family of related substances that bind to the energy - providing molecule atp and regulate functions such as cell division and signalling between cells 
kine -  ||  prefix movement 
kinematics  ||  noun the science of movement , especially of body movements 
kineplasty  ||  noun an amputation in which the muscles of the stump of the amputated limb are used to operate an artificial limb ( note :  the plural is kineplasties .  ) 
kinesi -  ||  prefix movement ( note :  used before vowels ) 
kinesiology  ||  noun the study of human movements , particularly with regard to their use in treatment kinesis noun the movement of a cell in response to a stimulus .  compare taxis 
 - kinesis  ||  suffix 1 .  activity or motion 2 .  a change in the movement of a cell , though not in any particular direction .  examples are a change in its speed or in its turning behaviour .  
kinesitherapy  ||  noun therapy involving movement of parts of the body 
kinetic  ||  adjective relating to movement 
kings fund  ||  noun a major independent health charity in london 
kings model  ||  noun a model of nurse–patient relationships based on ten principles :  interaction , perception , communication , transaction , role , stress , growth and development , time , self and space .  through an exchange of information nurses and patients work together to help individuals and groups attain , maintain and restore health .  
kinin  ||  noun a polypeptide that makes blood vessels widen and smooth muscles contract 
kirschner wire  ||  , kirschners wire noun a wire attached to a bone and tightened to provide traction to a fracture [described 1909 .  after martin kirschner ( 1879– 1942 ) , professor of surgery at heidelberg , germany . ] 
kiss of life  ||  noun same as cardiopulmonary resuscitation ( informal ) kj abbr kilojoule 
klebsiella  ||  noun a gram - negative bacterium , one form of which , klebsiella pneumoniae , can cause pneumonia 
klebs - loeffler bacillus  ||  noun the bacterium which causes diphtheria , corynebacterium diphtheriae [after theodor albrecht klebs ( 1834–1913 ) , bacteriologist in zürich , switzerland , and chicago , usa ; friedrich august loeffler ( 1852–1915 ) , bacteriologist in berlin , germany] 
kleihauer test  ||  , kleihauer - betke test noun a test used to check whether there has been any blood loss from a fetus to the mother across the placenta .  it is usually done immediately after delivery .  
klepto -  ||  prefix stealing or theft 
kleptomania  ||  noun a form of mental disorder in which someone has a compulsive desire to steal things , even things of little value

( b .  1912 ) , associate professor of medicine , john hopkins medical school , baltimore , usa . ] 
klumpkes paralysis  ||  noun a form of paralysis due to an injury during birth , affecting the forearm and hand .  also called déjerine - klumpkes syndrome [described 1885 .  after augusta klumpke ( madame déjerine - klumpke ) ( 1859–1937 ) , french neurologist , one of the first women to qualify in paris in 1888 . ]

knee joint  ||  noun a joint where the femur and the tibia are joined , covered by the

–knitted – knit )

knock out  ||  verb to hit someone so hard that he or she is no longer conscious  he was knocked out by a blow on the head .  
knuckle  ||  noun the back of each joint on a persons hand 
kocher manoeuvre  ||  noun a method for realigning a dislocated shoulder in which the arm is raised and a sudden change is made between inward and outward rotation of the head of the joint

koch - weeks bacillus  ||  noun the bacillus which causes conjunctivitis 
köhlers disease  ||  noun a degeneration of the navicular bone in children .  also called scaphoiditis [described 1908 and 1926 .  after alban köhler ( 1874–1947 ) , german radiologist . ] 
koilonychia  ||  noun a condition in which the fingernails are brittle and concave , caused by iron - deficiency anaemia 
kopliks spots  ||  plural noun small white spots with a blue tinge surrounded by a red areola , found in the mouth in the early stages of measles [described 1896 .  after henry koplik ( 1858–1927 ) , us paediatrician . ] 
korotkoffs method  ||  noun a method of finding a persons blood pressure by inflating a cuff around his or her upper arm to a pressure well above the systolic blood pressure and then gradually decreasing it 
korsakoffs syndrome  ||  noun a condition , caused usually by chronic alcoholism or disorders in which there is a deficiency of vitamin b , in which a persons memory fails and he or she invents things which have not happened and is confused [described 1887 .  after sergei sergeyevich korsakoff ( 1854–1900 ) , russian psychiatrist . ] 
kraurosis penis  ||  noun a condition in which the foreskin becomes dry and shrivelled 
kraurosis vulvae  ||  noun a condition in which the vulva becomes thin and dry due to lack of oestrogen , found usually in elderly women 
krause corpuscles  ||  plural noun encapsulated nerve endings in the mucous membrane of the mouth , nose , eyes and genitals [described 1860 .  after wilhelm johann friedrich krause ( 1833–1910 ) , german anatomist . ] 
krebs cycle  ||  noun same as citric acid cycle [described 1937 .  after sir hans adolf krebs ( 1900–81 ) , german biochemist who emigrated to england in 1934 .  shared the nobel prize for medicine 1953 with f . a .  lipmann . ] 
krukenberg tumour  ||  noun a malignant tumour in the ovary secondary to a tumour in the stomach [after friedrich krukenberg ( 1871–1946 ) , german gynaecologist] 
kuntscher nail  ||  , küntscher nail noun a long steel nail used in operations to pin fractures of long bones , especially the femur , through the bone marrow [described 1940 .  after gerhard küntscher ( 1900–72 ) , german surgeon . ] 
kupffers cells  ||  , kupffer cells plural noun large specialised liver cells which break down haemoglobin into bile [described 1876 .  after karl wilhelm von kupffer ( 1829– 1902 ) , german anatomist . ] 
kveim test  ||  noun a skin test to confirm the presence of sarcoidosis [after morten ansgar kveim ( b .  1892 ) , swedish physician] 
kwashiorkor  ||  noun malnutrition of small children , mostly in tropical countries , causing anaemia , wasting of the body and swollen liver

lab  ||  noun same as laboratory ( informal )  the samples have been returned by the lab .   we’ll send the specimens away for a lab test .

lability of mood  ||  noun a tendency for a persons mood to change suddenly

labioplasty  ||  noun a surgical operation to repair damaged or deformed lips ( note :  the plural is labioplasties .  ) 
labium  ||  noun 1 .  any of the four fleshy folds which surround the female genital organs 2 .  a structure which looks like a lip ( note :  the plural is labia .  ) 
labor  ||  noun us spelling of labour 
laboratory  ||  noun a special room or place where scientists can do specialised work such as research , the testing of chemical substances or the growing of tissues in culture  the samples of water from the hospital have been sent to the laboratory for testing .   the new drug has passed its laboratory tests .  ( note :  the plural is laboratories .  ) 
laboratory officer  ||  noun a qualified person in charge of a laboratory 
laboratory technician  ||  noun a person who does practical work in a laboratory and has particular care of equipment 
laboratory techniques  ||  plural noun the methods or skills needed to perform experiments in a laboratory 
laboratory test  ||  noun a test carried out in a laboratory 
labour  ||  noun childbirth , especially the contractions in the uterus which take place during childbirth  in labour experiencing the physical changes such as contractions in the uterus which precede the birth of a child  she was in labour for 14 hours .   to go into labour to start to experience the contractions which indicate the birth of a child is imminent  she went into labour at 6 o’clock .  comment :  labour usually starts about nine months , or 266 days , after conception .  the cervix expands and the muscles in the uterus contract , causing the amnion to burst .  the muscles continue to contract regularly , pushing the baby into , and then through , the vagina .  
laboured breathing  ||  noun difficult breathing , which can be due to various causes such as asthma 
labour pains  ||  plural noun the pains felt at regular intervals by a woman as the muscles of the uterus contract during childbirth 
labrum  ||  noun a ring of cartilage around the rim of a joint ( note :  the plural is la - bra .  ) 
labyrinth  ||  noun a series of interconnecting tubes , especially those in the inside of the ear comment :  the labyrinth of the inner ear is in three parts :  the three semicircular canals , the vestibule and the cochlea .  the osseous labyrinth is filled with a fluid ( perilymph ) and the membranous labyrinth is a series of ducts and canals inside the osseous labyrinth .  the membranous labyrinth contains a fluid ( endolymph ) .  as the endolymph moves about in the membranous labyrinth it stimulates the vestibular nerve which communicates the sense of movement of the head to the brain .  if a person turns round and round and then stops , the endolymph continues to move and creates the sensation of giddiness .  
labyrinthectomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to remove the labyrinth of the inner ear ( note :  the plural is labyrinthectomies .  ) 
labyrinthitis  ||  noun same as otitis interna 
lacerated  ||  adjective torn or with a rough edge 
lacerated wound  ||  noun a wound where the skin is torn , as by a rough surface or barbed wire 
laceration  ||  noun 1 .  a wound which has been cut or torn with rough edges , and is not the result of stabbing or pricking 2 .  the act of tearing tissue 
lachrymal  ||  adjective same as lacrimal 
lacrimal  ||  adjective referring to tears , the tear ducts or the tear glands .   nasolacrimal 
lacrimal apparatus  ||  noun the arrangement of glands and ducts which produce and drain tears .  also called lacrimal system 
lacrimal bone  ||  noun one of two little bones which join with others to form the orbits 
lacrimal canaliculus  ||  noun a small canal draining tears into the lacrimal sac 
lacrimal caruncle  ||  noun a small red point at the inner corner of each eye 
lacrimal duct  ||  noun a small duct leading from the lacrimal gland .  also called tear duct 
lacrimal gland  ||  noun a gland beneath the upper eyelid which secretes tears .  also called tear gland 
lacrimal puncta  ||  plural noun small openings of the lacrimal canaliculus at the corners of the eyes through which tears drain into the nose 
lacrimal sac  ||  noun a sac at the upper end of the nasolacrimal duct , linking it with the lacrimal canaliculus 
lacrimal system  ||  noun same as lacrimal apparatus 
lacrimation  ||  noun the production of tears 
lacrimator  ||  noun a substance which irritates the eyes and makes tears flow 
lacrymal  ||  , lachrymal  ||  adjective another spelling of lacrimal 
lact -  ||  prefix same as lacto - ( used before vowels ) 
lactase  ||  noun an enzyme , secreted in the small intestine , which converts milk sugar into glucose and galactose 
lactate  ||  verb to produce milk in the body ( note :  lactating – lactated ) 
lactation  ||  noun 1 .  the production of milk in the body 2 .  the period during which a mother is breastfeeding a baby comment :  lactation is stimulated by the production of the hormone prolactin by the pituitary gland .  it starts about three days after childbirth , before which period the breasts secrete colostrum .  
lacteal  ||  adjective referring to milk  noun a lymph vessel in a villus which helps the digestive process in the small intestine by absorbing fat 
lactic  ||  adjective relating to milk 
lactic acid  ||  noun a sugar which forms in cells and tissue , and also in sour milk , cheese and yoghurt comment :  lactic acid is produced as the body uses up sugar during exercise .  excessive amounts of lactic acid in the body can produce muscle cramp .  
lactiferous  ||  adjective producing , secreting or carrying milk 
lactiferous duct  ||  noun a duct in the breast which carries milk 
lactiferous sinus  ||  noun a dilatation of the lactiferous duct at the base of the nipple 
lacto - prefix referring to milk 
lactobacillus  ||  noun a genus of gram - positive bacteria which produces lactic acid from glucose and may be found in the digestive tract and the vagina 
lactogenic hormone  ||  noun same as prolactin 
lactose  ||  noun a type of sugar found in milk 
lactose intolerance  ||  noun a condition in which a person cannot digest lactose because lactase is absent in the intestine or because of an allergy to milk , causing diarrhoea 
lactosuria  ||  noun the excretion of lactose in the urine 
lactovegetarian  ||  noun a person who does not eat meat , but eats vegetables , fruit , dairy produce and eggs and sometimes fish  he has been a lactovegetarian for twenty years .  compare vegan , vegetarian 
lactulose  ||  noun an artificially produced sugar used as a laxative 
lacuna  ||  noun a small hollow or cavity ( note :  the plural is lacunae .  ) 
lacunar  ||  adjective relating to hollows or cavities in tissue such as in bone or cartilage , especially ones that are unusual 
laënnecs cirrhosis  ||  noun the commonest form of alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver [described 1819 .  after rené théophile hyacinthe laennec ( 1781–1826 ) , professor of medicine at the collège de france , and inventor of the stethoscope . ] 
laevocardia  ||  noun the condition of having the heart in the usual position , with the apex towards the left side of the body .  compare dextrocardia 
 - lalia  ||  suffix speech or a speech disorder 
lambda  ||  noun 1 .  the 11th letter of the greek alphabet 2 .  the point at the back of the skull where the sagittal suture and lambdoidal suture meet

lamblia  ||  noun same as giardia

lame  ||  adjective not able to walk easily because of pain , stiffness or damage in a leg or foot ( note :  this term is regarded as offensive .  )

french physician] landsteiners classification  ||  noun same as abo system

laryngectomy  ||  noun a surgical operation to remove the larynx , usually as treatment for throat cancer ( note :  the plural is laryngectomies .  ) 
larynges  ||  plural of larynx 
laryngismus  ||  , laryngismus stridulus  ||  noun a spasm of the throat muscles with a sharp intake of breath which occurs when the larynx is irritated , as in children who have croup
